(0:03) All right, so this is my session 10 assignment. (0:08) All right, so the objective is pretty straightforward for this assignment. (0:12) Management is considering a $12 million upfront investment with a 10-year operational horizon, (0:17) and my goal is to determine if this project creates shareholder value using the firm's 8.5% (0:21) walk as the hurdle rate.
To ensure that there was a rigorous analysis, I applied the driver (0:28) framework, which I'll walk through now. So first, we would define Discover. This is the most (0:35) crucial step.
So I defined the problem as an incremental cash flow analysis. We're not looking (0:39) at total company revenue, but specifically the new cash entering and leaving the firm solely (0:44) because of this draw straight. During the Discover phase, I isolated the specific parameters from the (0:54) as described right here.
We have an initial $12 million capital expenditure for building (1:01) and equipment. It's a 10-year project. We're using straight line depreciation, which means we will (1:06) expense $1.2 million annually.
This is a non-cash expense, but crucial for calculating the tax (1:11) yield. I also mapped out the operational assumptions. Revenue follows a ramp-up (1:18) peak and stabilized pattern, starting at $8 million, peaking at $11 million, and settling (1:23) at $9 million.
Costs are a mix of variable and fixed. The cost of goods is variable at about 40%. (1:29) Labor and rent are fixed at about $3.3 million combined, and this indicates high operating (1:34) leverage, which is a risk factor I noted to test later.
Finally, I discovered two specific cash (1:39) flow adjustments after working capital. We deployed $500k at year 0. This is a cash outflow now, but (1:45) we treat it as cash inflow at year 10. We expect to sell the assets for $3 million in year 10.
(1:50) However, since we depreciated the assets at $0 over 10 years, the full $3 million is taxable gain (1:56) at a 25% tax rate. The net cash inflow is actually only at $2.25 million. (2:01) With these variables defined, I moved on to the next phase.
(2:20) I structured the analysis to solve for unlevered free cash flow. The logic is calculate EBIT, (2:27) which is just revenue minus operating expense and depreciation. Apply the 25% tax rate to get the (2:33) net operating profit after tax, add back depreciation, and subtract capital expenditures (2:39) and changes in working capital.
This gives us the true cash that's distributable to investors, (2:44) we can discount back to year 0 using the 8.5 MOC. (2:52) Now moving on to the next step. As you can see in the code here, (2:56) I created a flexible function called calculate cash flows, which is right over here.
It takes (3:02) inputs like WOC, revenue modifiers, and tax rate at parameters. It iterates the years 0 to 10, (3:07) and then automatically handles the logic for marketing budget drop-off after year 1 and the (3:12) WOC recovery in year 10. Then I also implemented separate blocks.
Here we can see NWC, (3:25) discounting different datas, and then jumping out to some other calculations, (3:32) calculating the NPV, IRR, simple payback, discounted payback, and profitability index. (3:38) These are all shown here. This allows me to change one revenue-like variable and (3:43) instantly see the impact on all five metrics.
I also did some sensitivity analysis (3:53) over here, and then added some visualizations over here. (4:00) But having said some of that, here this comes for the validation part. So I ran base case scenario (4:06) to ensure that numbers align with the financial situation and the results are positive, (4:11) which we can jump down to right over here.
So the NPV, we can see that (4:31) after doing the actual calculations, the value comes out to about 2.6 million down there. (4:38) And since that value is greater than zero, the project creates value. The IRR came out to about (4:46) 12.84%, which comfortably clears the 8.5% hurdle rate.
And the payback, the firm recovers its (4:53) initial cash investment at 5.28 years and then recovers the present value of that at 8.21. (5:02) Given the 10-year horizon, a six-year discounted payback is acceptable, (5:07) and the base case is financially round. Here, there's also the cash flow schedule from years (5:12) zero to 10. These visualizations just shows the actual cash flow schedule between all the years (5:20) that we have and millions of dollars.
We can see year zero is quite negative, and then it slowly (5:25) goes up back up to positive for the rest of the years. And we can see that this is the payback (5:31) trajectory. So when the investment comes back to breakeven, we've got a breakeven.
(5:45) Breakeven will be roughly around year eight, roughly right about there. So it's roughly (5:54) about eight years, which I said earlier as well. That's about where the breakeven is.
And then (5:59) this is just a sensitivity analysis to see how, according to the NPV impact, (6:07) how sensitive are these different metrics of the walk at two different parts of revenue. (6:12) And for the base case, you can see the different sensitivities there. (6:17) Now moving on.
So as I mentioned before, we are using the base case saying it's financially sound. (6:23) However, that is just a best guess. I also stress tested it.
Here we could see that that's kind of (6:33) exactly what that sensitivity analysis exactly. So even if the cost of capital spikes to 10.5%, (6:39) the NPV remains positive at roughly, yeah, even if it goes up, it comes out to still above positive (6:52) number, which is still zero. It's right about there.
Revenue shock. This is a critical finding (6:58) and model scenario where revenue drops 20, where it drops 20%. The NPV drops to a negative 3 million (7:11) and IRR falls below the hurdle rate right here at 3.13. This confirms the early suspicion about (7:17) operating leverage because rent and labor are fixed, a drop in top line sales for its profitability (7:21) disproportionately.
Finally, we arrive at reflect. And based on this analysis, my recommendation is (7:31) to accept the flagship grocery project. The rationale is threefold.
The base case NPV (7:37) and the profitability index indicates efficient use of capital and the flagship grocery likely (7:43) provides a halo effect for the brand driving traffic to standard stores, a benefit not even (7:48) captured in these numbers. We must also acknowledge the revenue risks since a 20% (7:52) miss destroys value. I recommend approval only if the marketing team can provide high confidence in (7:57) year one sales targets of 8 million.
And if year one sales trend below 7 million, (8:03) cost cutting measures of labor must be triggered immediately. Thank you.

Answer:
Hello, my name is Sarah, and this presentation walks through my DRIVER-guided financial analysis of Starbucks' proposed flagship roastery project. I'll explain the modeling approach, show how Python was used to automate the calculations, and present the final investment recommendation.

The problem is to determine whether Starbucks should invest $12 million in a flagship roastery expected to operate for 10 years. Starbucks' hurdle rate is 8.5%, so the key question is whether the project creates value as measured by NPV, IRR, and other capital-budgeting metrics.

I gathered all project parameters from the assignment: revenue forecasts, cost structure, depreciation, taxes, working capital, and terminal value. I also reviewed standard methods for NPV, IRR, profitability index, and payback analysis."

I designed a year-by-year incremental cash-flow model that calculates EBIT, taxes, NOPAT, depreciation add-back, working-capital changes, and terminal value. Python was chosen because it makes the model fully reproducible and allows automated sensitivity analysis."

To ensure accuracy, I verified that depreciation was correctly applied, terminal value and working-capital adjustments were only in Year 10, and sensitivity outputs behaved as expected. The model ran successfully end-to-end.

Here are the results. The base-case NPV is approximately +3.02 million. The IRR is 13.33%, above the 8.5% WACC. The profitability index is 1.25, and the payback periods are reasonable. The sensitivity tests show the project remains positive under discount-rate changes but becomes negative if revenue falls by 20%

This chart shows free cash flows over time. The large outflow occurs at Year 0 from investment and working capital, followed by stable positive flows and a terminal value in Year 10.
The second chart shows NPV sensitivity. The base case is positive, revenue downside is negative, and both WACC adjustments remain positive.

Through the DRIVER process, I learned the importance of structured analysis, parametric modeling, and stress-testing assumptions to understand risk."

Based on positive NPV, strong IRR, and strategic alignment with Starbucks' brand identity, I recommend that Starbucks proceed with the flagship roastery investment. While revenue risk is the primary concern, the project still meets financial hurdles under normal conditions.

Thank you for listening. I'm happy to answer any questions.

Answer: Hi, my name is Noah and uh for this assignment we're going to focus on session 10 which is capital budgeting and investment decisions and specifically for this assignment uh we are going to do an analysis on the cost of capital. So the context and objective of this assignment as a whole is that we have to evaluate Starbucks proposed flagship roster that requires a 12 million upfront outlay and is expected to operate for 10 years. So to do this, we're going to use the firm's 8.5% walk as the hurdle rate to determine whether the product creates value and then use that to recommend an accept or reject decision supported by uh the driver framework. And um specifically for this assignment, we have to focus the analysis on producing a transparent cash flow model, core capital, budget metrics, sensitivity test, and an executive ready recommendation. Uh as you can see here, we have all uh the project parameters, but I will go into detail using the drive method. Uh so I'll go in more detail as we go through this video. So in the first method we have to define and discover and uh the objective is to tell the executives at Starbucks if spending 12 million today to build a flagship grocery is a smart financial move. So this is the the the yes or no question and the decision will be based on the net present value rule. So also known as the MP rule. So what is that? Uh essentially if the project generates more value in today's dollars than it costs we will accept it. If not we reject it. So um really basic uh as a whole and in the define and discover stage we have to kind of know what we know what we don't know and um and yeah so here we have the parameters of the known so this is every piece of data that we have to catalog. So we don't miss anything before we actually start coding. So we have the the timeline and investment. So we have the project lifespan, the upfront cost, uh the working capital for zero year zero, the working capital recovery for year 10 and uh the depreciation and uh we have operations which is uh money coming in versus going out. So this includes uh revenue uh cost of goods sold, labor, rent and utilities and of course market. And uh we also have the financial rates and value. So the tax rate uh the discount rate so the the weighted average uh cost of capital which is the walk and which serves as our hurter rate which the the project must return more than this. And uh at at the end we have also the terminal value. And then we also have the unknowns which is uh the free cash flow for years uh 1 through 10, the net present value, the IRR which is the internal rate of return, the payback period uh simple and discounted and uh the profitability index and the sensitivity analysis. So uh considering if revenue drops or if the hurdle rate uh were to to be higher or lower and uh why do we need this? So what is the point of all this? So imagine you're buying a very expensive lemonade stand. The fine phase is where we list the price of the stand. So the initial investment, how much lemon and sugar cost, so the operating expenses and how much we plan to sell it. So the revenue but there is a catch. So a dollar earned 10 years from now is worth less than a dollar uh today due to inflation. So we need to define our discount rate the one which acts like an exchange rate to translate future money into today's value. With all of this already defined and and uh kind of set up, we we have it perfect to to move on to the represent stage where the objective is to structure our logic into three distinct blocks. And now this kind of uh evolves because um once I enter the validate um point of my my actual code, I started thinking to myself, well, is this project fragile? So in the financial value in the best case the project clears our 8.5% hurdle rate and generates 3 million in value. In the strategic value, as a flagship grocery, this location acts as a billboard for the Starbucks brand. Even if it breaks even, the market value is significant. Answer:
Hello, my name is Krish, and I have conducted a full financial evaluation of Starbucks's proposed flagship Roastery concept. My goal was to determine whether this project creates value for shareholders using a rigorous capital budgeting model built around discounted cash flows, sensitivity analysis, and the NPV decision rule. To structure my analysis clearly, I walk, I will walk through the DRIVER framework.

To begin with the D part of the DRIVER framework, the objective of this analysis was straightforward: to determine whether Starbucks should invest $12 million upfront to build and operate a flagship Roastery that would run for 10 years. So this required projecting the Roastery's future free cash flow, discounting them using Starbucks's 8.5% WACC, and applying the NPV rule, which states: if NPV is greater than zero, the project adds value and should be accepted, or if the NPV is lesser than zero, the project destroys value and should be rejected. Because I'm evaluating a project within Starbucks's existing business, using the company's WACC as the hurdle rate is the correct approach. WACC represents the blended requirement's return from shareholders and lenders for projects of comparable risks. My goal was to compute these financial metrics and also generate a clear business recommendation grounded in numbers, supported by sensitivity analysis, and communicated in a way suitable for decision-makers.

Moving ahead for the R where I outlined the core requirements and assumptions that defined the project's operating and financial structure. These assumptions serve as the backbone of the model. So, first I looked at the Initial Investment and Depreciation. So Starbucks would spend $12 million upfront on the building, equipment, and training. This amount is depreciated straight-line over 10 years, producing a $1.2 million in annual depreciation, which is important because it creates a depreciation tax shield that improves after-tax cash flows.

The second is the Working Capital, which shows that the project requires $500,000 of working capital at launch. And working capital is not an expense but an investment that is fully recovered in 10 years.

The third is the Revenue. In the first year, Starbucks is expected to have $8 million in revenue, then from Year 2 to 5, $11 million each year, and then in Year 6 to 10, $9 million each year.

The Operating Costs was something which I looked into. Then the Taxes, how Starbucks uses a 25% corporate tax rate. Then the Terminal Value, like how at the end of 10 years the Roastery has a Terminal Value of $3 million, which is added to the final year's cash flow.

The seventh is the Discount Rate. The project cash flows are discounted using the Starbucks's 8.5% WACC, which is the correct rate because we are evaluating a long-term operating project with similar risk of Starbucks's core business.

Next, moving on to the I part where I have to Interpret... I evaluated whether the Roastery creates value. I did this by building a detailed annual cash flow model that translated these assumptions into Free Cash Flows, the actual economic value generated for Starbucks. So the steps to build this were: first, to take the project revenue and the operating operating costs, then incorporating depreciation and taxes, then adding back the depreciation for the depreciation tax shield, and then the fourth thing is to include the working capital adjustments, then the terminal value, and the discounting cash flows at the last.

To Validate my model, I took the results from the base case financial model, which is: NPV is + $2.69 million, IRR is 12.84%, Profitability Index is 1.22, Discounted Payback Period is 8.2 years, and Undiscounted Payback Period is 5.3 years.

Furthermore, to Evaluate the Sensitivities... I ran a sensitivity analysis on the variables most likely to change. First, the Revenue Sensitivity was the most volatile assumption in detail, so I tested the NPV change if revenue is 10% higher or lower. And then the WACC Sensitivity, then the Labor Cost Sensitivity. And I interpreted the sensitivity results. So, across all tests, the project continues to produce a positive NPV. This means the recommendation is robust, even if costs increase or demand underperforms, the Roastery will still create value for Starbucks.

And lastly, the Recommendation says, while I bring all this together, my recommendation is to accept the project. Because my decision is supported by a positive NPV of $2.6 million, an IRR well above the 8.5% WACC, a strong Profitability Index of 1.22, and a consistent positive result across multiple sensitivity scenarios. I feel that the Roastery is not only financially viable but strategically aligned with Starbucks's brand building approach and resilient under practical downside scenarios.

So in summary, based on a rigorous capital budgeting analysis, the Starbucks's flagship Roastery value is... the Roastery is a value-creating investment, and Starbucks should move forward with the project.

Looking at my code, we can see here how the cash flow table is shown for every year, year by year, for 10 years. We can see the core capital budgeting metrics: the WACC, the NPV, the IRR, the undiscounted payback, and the discounted payback. The sensitivity for the selected scenarios. And we can see how the year-by-year cash flows are shown in a graph or table, which helps visualize better. Moving forward, I have also included the DRIVER summary in my code to make it easier to understand.

So the first Define part shows how Starbucks's flagship Roastery has a 10-year life, initial outlay, then the working capital, WACC. Then the R part shows the depreciation, terminal scale, operating assumptions. The Input is shown, the Validation is shown, the Execute is shown where the decision rule is to accept if NPV is greater than zero and if IRR is greater than WACC, and my recommendation is to Accept. I have also given the Risks and Next Steps. So the top risks is that revenue shortfall, labor cost will escalate, and higher financing costs or larger CapEx. Then the suggestions for the next steps are to run a stress test, an alternative terminal assumption, or a phased investment plan.

Thank you.

Today we're going to be talking about Starbucks and their decision to invest $12 million into a roastery project. So our goal is to determine if this investment will create revenue. The hurdle rate for Starbucks or the weight adjusted cost of capital is 8.5%. Meaning that's a rate of return that we need to get back in order to make money. And the project life is 10 years. So the financial environment that we have is for the first year they're going to make $8 million. For years two through five they're going to make $11 million. And then years 6 through 10, they're going to make $9 million off this investment. The cost of goods sold is 40%. Labor is $2.5 million. Rent and utilities are $800,000. Marketing for the first year for the project will be 300,000 and then sub subsequently $100,000 each year. Depreciation is $1.2 million per year. The working capital is we have 500k invested which will be recovered in the last year. Terminal value is $3 million and the tax rate is 25%.

So looking at the represent we are going to build a year 0 to 10 cash flow schedule of showing where our money is going to be. The operating cash flow equals the net income plus the depreciation. We're going to include working capital changes. Add the terminal value at the end and compute the net present value, internal rate of cont return, payback and discounted payback and the profitability index. Then we are going to compute the financial situation in which the revenue is adjusted plus minus 20%. And the weight adjusted cost to capital is adjusted to 6.5% and 10.5% which is respectively plus or minus 2%. Then we're going to compare the net present value and internal rate of return across those cases. And then we're going to advise Starbucks if the project is good for them, if they should invest in it, if the project should be completed. Looking first at the um cash flows for the Starbucks roaster, we can see that year zero represents the initial investment which shows the large negative cash flow. So showing that they are going to be net negative in that year for that investment. But then years 1 through 5 show an inflow of positive money from the investment which is a good return automatically. Most projects take at least a couple years to get a return going. So the fact that this in year one already has above positive returns is a good sign. And then so we can see that the 11 million years drop down. The 11 million return drops off after year five. And in year six there is a less return. But then this sharp increase in year 10 is when the 500,000 is added back of the working capital. So that is a insight into how this graph reflects and even though we are losing a lot of money at the beginning it is an investment and we will gain money and be net positive for those quarters or years. So looking at the computed values, the net present value is going to be 3,22,514

which symbolizes that we are going to be making that much money off of this investment which is a good sign already. The internal rate of return is 13.25% which is very good higher than our hurdle rate which is a thing that we want to mention already. Profitability index is 1.252 252 a good above one simple payback period is in year six and the discounted payback period is in year 9. So if we look at the graph we can kind of tell or start to assume some things about the graph. When we look at year six we can tell that that these start to become the discounted payback periods where that might be why the cash flows go down also because of lack of money. But it shows that these are the best periods to pay back from year 6 to 9. As in year 10, the cash flow goes up again with the added back. So those are some calculations that me and Gemini worked on which was very helpful using the financial environment. I got to learn a lot about that. So that was great.

So looking back on to our results, this the net present value is greater than zero. It is $3 million which means that the project will create value. In fact, it'll create that $3 million if the financial environment holds steady the way that we think it will. The internal rate of 13.25% is greater than the weight adjusted cost of capital of 8.5% which means that returns will exceed the hurdle rate which is another positive. The profitability index is greater than one which means that $1.25 will be returned for every $1 invested. Another good positive. As long as that is above one, that is often a good sign as we will be making money. The payback period of year six and the discounted year 9 are reasonable payback periods for a retail investment as this will give them time to increase their profits while also introducing other projects to pay back for the retail investments. And it gives them a good working time to figure out how they're going to pay for it. As Starbucks is a major company, they are very trustworthy to pay back their investments. So they probably work with a lot of different investment companies making it easier for them to get the funding. So the work and then working capital is recovered in year 10. So looking at the evolve with the 20% minus revenue, we can tell that if we lose revenue, we do not want to invest in this project as the net present value would lose us $3 million and the internal rate of return would be significantly lower than our hurdle rate, which would be apparent by the net present value as we do not want to lose $3 million. Subsequently with a 20% increase, obviously we would want to invest again as we'd be making even more money. Dr. Z’s textbook: https://cinderzhang.github.io. 
Complete the work as outlined. 

Submit ONLY your YouTube video link for this session assignment. Requirements: (1) No video file uploads - link only; (2) Video must be viewable by instructor (set as unlisted if you don't want it public); (3) Must have transcripts turned on; (4) Follow assignment instructions.

Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

STEP 3: Submit on Brightspace

Paste YouTube link in the submission area

STEP 4: Verify Access

Test your links in an incognito browser window
If you can't view it, neither can I = automatic zero
Key point: I just need to be able to watch it - Public or Unlisted both work

Submit your transcript pure text. This must be the exact transcript from your YouTube video with transcripts turned on. 

Copy and paste your video transcript directly in the text box (from YouTube's auto-generated captions or your own transcript - DO NOT attach files)

Answer:
Hi, my name is Will Borowski, and today I'm going to be presenting our comprehensive capital budgeting analysis for the Starbucks proposed flagship roaster project. This is a $12 million strategic decision, and our job as financial analysts is to cut through the excitement and ensure that this investment creates tangible shareholder value. We'll be using the firm's 8.5% Weighted Average Cost of Capital, or WACC, as our minimum hurdle rate, and the Net Present Value decision rule as our golden standard.

Our analysis rigorously follows the DRIVER framework, which ensures a disciplined, step-by-step approach. First, in the 'Define and Discover' stage, we frame the problem: Does this 10-year project, with its complex cash flow patterns, earn returns above the 8.5% cost of capital? We immediately identified all incremental cash flow components: the initial $12 million equipment cost; a temporary but necessary $500,000 working capital outflow at time zero, which is fully recovered at the end; a multi-phased annual operating cash flow driven by revenue changes; a depreciation tax shield from the $1.2 million annual straight-line depreciation; and finally, the crucial terminal value in year 10, which includes both the working capital recovery and the after-tax value of the asset.

Moving to the 'Represent and Implement' parts of this, we moved these components onto a 10-year timeline and automated the entire process using Python. Here is our script. As you can see, we coded it and imported multiple modules to ensure we got a good final result. The complexity here lies in the phased revenue: $8 million initially, peaking at $11 million in the mature phase, and declining to $9 million. This requires a dynamic, year-by-year cash flow calculation. The most common error in capital budgeting is the terminal value. The assignment gave us the gross salvage value of $3 million. Since this asset is fully depreciated, we must correctly calculate the after-tax salvage value. For our after-tax salvage value, we got $2.25 million. This is the correct value that flows into our year 10 calculation, which, along with the half-million dollar working capital recovery and the final OCF, yields the 10-year net cash flow value of $4.55 million.

And as you can see down here, this is where we got that $4.55 million cash flow.

Now let's review the base case financial metrics using the 8.5% WACC. As we scroll down here, you see that we got the 8.5% WACC. The Net Present Value is calculated as a positive $2.69 million. A positive NPV is our primary indicator, telling us that the project generates $2.69 million in value above and beyond what is required to compensate our investors at 8.5%. The project's Internal Rate of Return is 12.84%. Since 12.84% is significantly greater than the 8.5% WACC, it confirms that the Net Present Value decision is financially attractive. Next, we get to the Profitability Index. The Profitability Index is 1.22 times. This means that for every dollar invested at time zero, the project generates $1.22 in present value of future cash flows. This is a strong acceptance signal. Then we get to the payback metrics, where the simple payback is 5.28 years and the discounted payback is 8.21 years. This project recovers the initial capital relatively quickly, well within the 10-year life, which addresses a key liquidity concern.

Financial analysis is incomplete without testing assumptions. The 'Validate and Evolve' stages test the robustness of our accept recommendation through sensitivity analysis. We focus on two major areas of risk: operational risk and market/financial risk. A flagship roaster's success hinges on attracting foot traffic and driving high sales. What happens if our revenue projections are optimistic by around 20%? Under this stress scenario, the NPV plummets from a positive $2.69 million to a deeply negative $3 million. The IRR falls dramatically to just 3.13%, which is less than half the WACC. The insight we gain from this is that the project is highly sensitive to revenue risk. Even a moderate sales shortfall transforms a project from a value creator into a value destroyer. This vulnerability must be addressed in the final recommendation.

For scenario B, we test financing risk. We tested the decision against a WACC range from 6.5% to 10.5%. As seen here, at a lower WACC of 6.5%, the NPV increases to $4.24 million. Crucially, even at a stressed WACC of 10.5%, the NPV remains at a positive $1.35 million. This project is robust to moderate increases in the cost of capital. The 12.84% IRR provides a healthy buffer against market fluctuations. This means the decision's vulnerability does not lie in financing, but purely in operations and revenue execution. This chart confirms the financial logic. The NPV line is clearly above the zero net present value line, as seen here.

Next, we see that the WACC range we tested indicates a profitability buffer. However, the extreme sensitivity to revenue shows that the profitability buffer is thin relative to sales volume risk. This project's economic viability hangs on hitting those sales targets.

This brings us to our final stage: reflection and the execution recommendation. The final conclusion is clear: based on the base case model, we should accept the project. It generates a $2.69 million net present value for shareholders, outperforming the cost of capital by over 400 basis points. However, our managerial recommendation must be conditional. The quantitative results demand we move forward, but the sensitivity analysis exposes a critical risk. The project cannot absorb a 20% drop in expected sales.

Next, we get to our strategic justification for brand and strategic fit. This roaster is not just a coffee shop; it's a flagship, a brand investment. Its value extends beyond a cash flow model and supports the premium brand image, which is a qualitative benefit that often justifies some financial conservatism. Next, we get to our financial leverage. The PI of 1.22 times is strong, and the quick simple payback of 5.28 years minimizes the time Starbucks' capital is at risk.

The actionable mitigation plan is this: before breaking ground, management must conduct a highly detailed market validation study to refine the sales forecast for the $11 million in the two-to-five-year phase. This strategic importance justifies the investment, but the financial risk determines better execution.

Certainly, this entire exercise confirms the central role of the NPV. It is a framework that systematically converts a complex idea into an objective, value-based metric. It cuts through the emotional arguments of supply chain independence and brand positioning and provides a single defensible number that guides a firm towards its ultimate goal: creating wealth for its shareholders. Thank you.

Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

Paste YouTube link in the submission area

Test your links in an incognito browser window

Answer: Hello. This is Isaac Buche, and this is my session 10 assignment. So starting off by like defining our parameters here, so we'll go over the site. Assignment, overview, evaluate. Starbucks is proposed flag flagship grocery that requires a 12 million upfront outlay, and it's expected to operate for 10 years. We're going to use the firm's 8.5% wa CC as a hurdle rate to determine whether the project creates value and to recommend and accept such reject the decision supported by the driver documentation. So going into some project parameters here, the initial investment is going to be $12 million and it'll depreciate in a straight just do a straight line depreciation method over 10 years. Our working capital is going to be 500,000 and deployed at launch and recovered in year 10. Our revenues is 8 million in year 111, and two and 11 million in years two through five, and then 9 million in years six through 10, our operating costs, our cost of goods sold, will be 40% of revenue, labor, two and a half million, rent and utilities at 800,000 point 8 million. Marketing will be at 300,000 so point 3 million or in year one, and then point 1 million thereafter, taxes, we're gonna be in the 25% range, terminal value of 3 million at the end of year 10. So jumping in, that's just our little that's defining what we were doing here. So jumping into like our calculations here, because as we're going into our assignment, I we want to build a zero to 10, your incremental cash flow schedule that includes revenue, operating cost, depreciation, tax shields taxes, working capital changes and terminal value. And we want to calculate our NPV, our IR and the discounted payback period, simple payback period and profitability index using the Starbucks WACC. Then we're going to run a sensitivity analysis using these numbers there, and then we're going to end up providing my recommendation at the end of this video. So jumping into our initial code here, starting off, we can run this code. Oops, we can run the code here, so then that obviously spits out our our requirements, so we jump into our MPV, our base calculation response, our NPV is 2,000,400 or 2,000,006 90 and 690,800.79 our IRR here is 12.8 point 12.84% Our payback period of 5.28 years, then our profitability index. So then this shows our cash flow schedule. So it starts as we're down here in the negative 12 million within our investment, and then our increments as we go up based upon our our profit from those years. So in our working capital, we will start the year off in the negatives in year, in year zero, and then positive, and we get back to the positives with our working capital by the year by the year 10. So does that logic makes sense there. And then we are and then, so then our IRR is greater than our 8.5% hurdle rate, which is good. So then we can pay back quickly. And then jumping into the second part of this, which was run the sensitivity analysis I ended up adding to this code here. So this is a new tab here, but in Scenario A when our revenue drops, we're looking at an NPV of negative three point around negative three, negative $3.084 million in loss, and then in Scenario B, when our WACC is six and a half percent, we we actually jumped to 4.23 6 million. And then our wa CC at 10.5% we at 1.35 so if revenue drops 20% our NPV turns negative, and the IRR drops to 5.7% so this indicates the project is highly sensitive to major performance, and then our WACC risk, which was Scenario B and C, if WACC rises 10 and a half percent. The NPV remains still positive at 1.1 so this project is very it's very fragile regarding volume of sales. So it's just interesting on how that can, like drastically change or impact the the overall sales through the project. But going into my final recommendation, my final recommendation is to accept the project. The flagship grocery generates an NPV of 2.4 3 million in the IRR of 12, of around 12% there. So I can come I can comfortably exceeding that 8.5% hurdle rate, so the profit, the profitability index is positive, indicating efficient capital usage. So just overall, the project should be successful with the numbers that we originally are at the it is could be optimally risky with the 20% drop in revenue. However, as a flagship project, the strategic value extends beyond immediate cash flows. It serves as a marketing vehicle for the broader Starbucks brand. So proceed with the investment, but I would implement a strict cost control with the initial investment of 12 million to build a little bit more safety into it for you. But that's it. And thank you for listening, and goodbye. Thank You.

Answer: So, in this video, I'm going to be walking through my capital budgeting analysis for Starbucks's proposed flagship roaster project. So, I structured the entire workflow using the driver framework. Define, discover, represent, implement, validate, evolve, and reflect. And you'll see each stage as I go through the notebook. So, first in the define stage, I laid out the core question we're trying to answer, which is should Starbucks invest 12 million million in this 10-year roastery project using their 8.5% WACC as hurdle rate. The decision rule is straightforward. If NPV is positive at 8.5%, the project creates shareholder value. Supporting metrics include irr payback periods and profitability index. Then in the discover step, I documented all relevant case assumptions including revenue patterns over the 10 years, operating costs like cost of goods sold, labor, rent, and marketing, working capital investment, straight line depreciation, a $3 million terminal value, and the 25% corporate tax rate. So, this step ensures that the entire analysis is transparent. And then here's that work um and grounded in the provided inputs. So next for section two in the represent stage I translated the business logic into a parameterized model. This cell loads all of the packages and stores every assumption in one place. Then here's that work. Um making the model easy to update later. So here's the printed summary. WACCC 8.5% tax rate 25% initial investment negative -12 million working capital negative0.5 million at year zero annual depreciation 1.2 2 million per year and a terminal value of 3 million at the end of year 10. Having this table clearly visible makes the upcoming calculations very easy to validate. So here I or here I implemented a reusable function that builds the entire year 0 through year 10 cash flow schedule. So you can see the table here. Year 0 shows the initial outflows. Free cash flow is -12.5 million which includes the capital investment plus working capital. From years 1 to 5, free cash flows are strong because revenue is highest in that window. Years 6 through 10 dip slightly due to lower revenue. And then finally in year 10, you can see a jump in free cash flow to 5.3 million because working capital is recovered and the terminal value of 3 million is added. So the table automatically calculates EBIT tax, EBIT taxes, depreciation, tax shields, operating cash flow, working capital changes, and terminal value. All right. Now, using the cash flow stream, I calculated all of the required capital budgeting metrics. So here are the results. NPV at 8.5% a WACC is a positive 3.023 million. So this is the primary decision metric. It's positive. So the project creates value. The IRR which is 13.3%. So the IRR is comfortably above the 8.5 hurdle rate. The simple payback which is around 5.28 years. The project recovers its initial outlay well before the 10-year life. Discounted payback at around 8.21 years. So slightly longer but still within the project's light lifespan. and then profitability index which is 1.242 meaning every $1 invested generates around $1.24 in value. All metrics point toward a strong base case financial performance. So now to evaluate robustness I ran two sensitivity tests. One was revenue with at - 20% scenario. So NVP NPV drops to -3.157 million turning negative and the IRRa collapses to 3.2% far below WACC. This shows the project is very sensitive to underperforming revenue. If foot traffic or con customer spends ends up weaker than expected the value can evaporate quickly. So number two, WACC is plus or minus 2%. So at 6.5% WACC, NPV increases to 4.636 million. And at 10.5% WACC, NPV remains positive but falls to 1.627 million. So this means financing conditions at Starbucks risk profile matter but not nearly as much as revenue performance. Across all scenarios the IRRa sets the IRRa itself doesn't change because irrra depends only on the cash flows and not discount rate. So now for section six this first chart visualizes the free cash flows across all years. So you can clearly see the large negative year zero outflow, strong operating cash flows during years 2 through 5, slightly smaller but stable cash flows afterward in a big year 10 spike from terminal value and working capital recovery. This confirms that the model behaves exactly as expected. So now for the next one, the second chart visualizes the NPV sensitivity. So the base case sits around positive $3 million. um revenue is negative 20% sends NPV deeply negative. WACC movements shift NPV up or down but keep posit but keep it positive. So this visualization supports the insight that revenue uncertainty is the primary risk driver for this project and then in the reflect phase I brought everything together. So financially the project should be accepted. NPV is positive. IRRa significantly exceeds WACC. Profitability index is above one. Paycheck period falls within the project life. Strategically, the project also fits Starbucks brand. So, it showcases the roasting craft. um strengthens the premium exper experential strategy, acts as a halo store that lifts the brand globally and some of the key risks includes revenue underperformance, high labor and occupancy costs, execution and construction delays and brand risk if the experience doesn't meet expectations. So our final decision is to accept here we are with it with its strong financial profile and strategic alignment but with attention to revenue risk the flagship roaster should be approved. So this concludes my driver guided analysis and implementation. Thank you so much for watching.

Answer: record. Hi, I'm Heidi and this is my session 10 homework. So for define and discover, our goal is to determine if the proposed $12 million flagship roster creates shareholder value. Our hurdle rate is the Starbucks weighted average cost of capital which is 8.5%. Our core decision rule is to accept the project if net present value is greater than zero. So here's some givens. Our initial investment is $12 million with a timing of at year zero and it has a nature of outflow because of the initial investment and our working capital is 0.5 million is also at year zero and and has a nature of outflow because it is deployed. Um we also have an annual cash flow which varies and the timing is between is from years 1 to 10 and it has inflows or outflows the because of operating cash flows and we have a terminal value of 3 million in year 10 and it it it is an inflow due to asset sale. Uh we have a working capital recovery of $0.5 million and it is also in year 10 and it has an inflow because of working capital recovered. Our project life is 10 years and our depreci we're assuming we have a straight line over 10 years depreciation and to get our depreciation we just use our initial investment of $12 million divided by 10 years and we get $1.2 million per year. And to for the represent we're using the following formulas. So first we're using operating cash flow formula which is equal to earning before interest in tax multipli by 1 minus taxes plus depreciation. And in this case earning before initial earning before interest in tax is equal to revenue minus operating cost minus depreciation. We're also using initial cash flow which in this case is calculated by investment minus working capital. So we get a negative of 12 12,500,000 and our annual operating cash flow which is between year 1 to 10. These are being calculated in using our implement which will be calculated annually using the full incremental cash flow schedule which will be provided in the implement section which we are also using terminal cash flow which is in year 10. So that equals to the terminal value plus working capsule recovery. So it is 3 million and $500,000. Here is the code that I asked Google Gemini to provide for me which provides the um cash flow of between year 1 to year 10 and it also provides a core capital budgeting matrix which is the base case and some sensitivity analysis for scenario A which is the reduction of 20% in reduction of reduction of 20% in revenue sorry and our scenario scenario B which is the base revenue but with a decrease in 2% in weighted average cost of capital or scenario C is the same base revenue and but with an increase in 2% in weighted average cost of capital. So to validate we we're using different those three methods. So first it is the cash flow verification. So we're you assuming the model correctly includes the initial investment working capital deployment and recovery operating cash flows incorporating revenue operating cost depreciation and the terminal value. So we're assuming we all use those correctly and we have a discount rate appropriation appropriateness. So the analysis uses the company's weighted average cost of capital which is in this case is 8.5% as the discount rate which is is the correct hurdle rate to reflect the opportunity cost of capital and we can also use the net present value methodology to confirm our calculation. So to use the formula that is provided in section 10. So the net present value formula um we we're saying that it is correctly applied and it discounting all future cash flow back to the present. And here's some summary. Here's a summary of sensitivity analysis. So we have a base case which is 8.5% of weighted average cost of capital and $3 million in net present value and our internal rate of return is 13.25%. 25%. This is our strong value. This is a strong value creation. And scenario A is when we reduce 20% in revenue. So that leads to the same 8.5% weighted average cost of capital. But in this case that that leads to a negative $2.75 million in net present value. And it also decreases the internal rate of return which is 3.88 to to 3.88%. So that means that the project is highly sensitive to revenue estimates. So a 20% drop makes the net present value negative and the internal rate of return just below the weighted average cost of capital. Scenario B is when we minus 2% on the weighted average cost of capital. So that leads to 6.5% in weighted average cost of capital. So that leads to a $4.64 64 million in net present value with um the same percentage 13.25% in internal rate of return that shows that higher net present value indicates that lower cost of capital significantly increases values. Weighted average cost of capital in scenario C we have a weighted average cost of capital but we um add 2% to it. So that leads to a 10.5% of weighted average cost of capital. So that leads to $1.63 million in net present value but with the same 13.25% in internal rate of return. So the project remains acceptable even with a higher cost of capital but the value created is significantly reduced. So comparing scenario B and C, we see that even though they both have a positive net present value and the same percentage for internal rate of return, but scenario C with a increase in weighted average cost of capital, we have a decrease in net present value. So for we have we have successfully created a s sensitivity analysis and we are recommendation integration. It will be shown in the reflect section and that shows that our learning um application is is provided and we have what we needed. So moving on to reflect. So um the reflect phase provides the final recommendation by weighting the quantitative financial results against qualitative strategic factors and project risks. So our financial results summary we have that this is using our base case. So we have a net present value of $3 million that is larger that is greater than zero or internal rate of return of 13.25 25% is greater than the weighted average cost of capital which is 8.5%. Or profitability index is 1.35 which is greater than one or payback. The project is expected to recover its initial investment quickly which the simple payback of 5.28 years and a discounted payback of 8.21 years. So a recommendation is to accept the sorry the flagship roaster project. So as a further to explain the positive net present value and internal rate of return coupled with the profitability index being greater than one clearly indicates that the project is expected to recreate shareholder values by earning returns significantly above Starbucks cost of capital. So our financial results has an assessment of of strong which in this case we have a net present value greater than zero or internal rate of return greater than the weighted average cost of return that indicates that we have a clear signal to accept based on the objective value creation. So according to the calculations that we created it is good to accept the project. Um we also have a strategic fit of with the assessment of high. So our um flagship roastery aligned with premium brand strategy, brand building and experimental retail. A key project risks is high revenue sensit is high revenue sensitivity. So that because according to a sensitivity analysis it shows the project is highly vulnerable to a 3 20% revenue miss shifting the net present value to negative. This risk requires robust marketing and operational plans or brand implications are also positive. So that enhancing so that indicates that enhancing brand image and allowing for premium branding testing and launching and providing qual qualitative benefits not captured in the financial model. So the overall the project demonstrates a robust financial performance in the base case with the net present value of $3 million indicates significant value creation. While the high sensitivity to revenue is the critical risk, the strategic benefits of a flagship location branding building market presence and retail innovation likely justify the investment. Providing manageable management establishes a con contingency plan to ensure revenue targets are met. So overall it is a great idea to accept the flagship roaster project according to the sensitivity analysis provided. Thank you.

And then We have the tax rate being 25% and then terminal value of $3 million at year 10, as well as our working capital is $500,000 at launch, which is year zero, and it would be recovered in year 10. Also, the depreciation for that is just a straight line over these 10 years. So you take the 12 million over or divide by the 10 years and that'll give you $1.2 million for that each year. So yeah, it's listed 8 million first year, you know, the 11 million from 2 to 5 and 9 million from 6 to 10 and then the 40% These numbers are 40% of these as we list in the information depreciation I told you how I got that with the 12 million divided by 10 and So yes, it, you know, just goes on from there. We have the operating cash flow, the EBIT, we have our taxes, our terminal value that we had there added that year 10 that we discussed and then how we got the 500 back and yeah, so total cash flow here and So that's kind of like representing related information that we just talked about. So to implement some of these numbers, along with taking the fact that it has an 8.5% WACC, we go over to the collab and we can calculate our net present value or NPV and then the IRR, the internal rate of return. So for that, I got $3,022,514. So a positive NPV means, you know, the project creates value because the present value of those future cash flows exceeds the upfront payment. So that is good. And then the IRR being at 13, I don't know why I didn't multiply it by 100, but 13.25%. And you know, this is higher than the 8.5% WACC we just looked at. So the project does clear the required return. But just also to preface, I, for some reason the collab was being like weird. Provide backup source of your YouTube submission. The content must be identical to your YouTube video. 

Add a backup video link from the LMS (Brightspace for example) or Vimeo (or similar commercial video platform) - must also be instructor and TA viewable

Follow the assignment directions for the appropriate session (e.g., Session 1 or Session 9 or Session 11) in 
Dr. Z’s textbook: https://cinderzhang.github.io. 
Complete the work as outlined. 

Submit ONLY your YouTube video link for this session assignment. Requirements: (1) No video file uploads - link only; (2) Video must be viewable by instructor (set as unlisted if you don't want it public); (3) Must have transcripts turned on; (4) Follow assignment instructions.

Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

STEP 3: Submit on Brightspace

Paste YouTube link in the submission area

STEP 4: Verify Access

Test your links in an incognito browser window
If you can't view it, neither can I = automatic zero
Key point: I just need to be able to watch it - Public or Unlisted both work

Submit your transcript pure text. This must be the exact transcript from your YouTube video with transcripts turned on. 

Copy and paste your video transcript directly in the text box (from YouTube's auto-generated captions or your own transcript - DO NOT attach files)

Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

STEP 3: Submit on Brightspace

STEP 4: Verify Access

Answer:
Hi, my name is Caden and this is my
assignment 10 for management 310. 
this is my analysis of the
proposed Starbucks flagship
roastery project.
The goal of this assignment is to
evaluate a $12 million
capital investment and provide a clear
accepts reject decision. To do this, I
have built a 10-year
cash flow model in Python, calculated a
core capital budgeting metrics, and
tested the project sensitivity to key
assumptions. My entire process was
followed by the driver framework which I
will use to structure the presentation
as required by the assignment. I began
with a clear define and discover stage
before any implications to ensure that
my model was built on a solid
foundation.
So the first stage the
define and discover
is where I define the core problem.
Should Starbucks accept this project?
The decision rule is clear. We will
accept if the project's net present
value is positive and if the internal
rate of return is greater than the
firm's 8.5%
WACC
in the section of my code access my
defined and discover documentation I
identified and listed all key project
parameters.
there's a 10-year project life, a
$12 million in initial investment, which
gives us a 1.2 2 million annual
depreciation expense.
a 500,000 working capital outlay
which will be recovered in
year 10. A $3 million
terminals salvage value and most
importantly a specific 10-year schedules
for revenue and marketing along with
variable and fixed operating costs.
documenting these assumptions first
was critical for building an accurate
model. Next this next stage was
represent
where I planned the project the model's
architect. My plan was to create a
single reusable function called run
analysis. You can see the plan outlined
in the comments here.
The reason for the structure is simple.
It adheres to the don't repeat yourself
principle. Instead of building separate
models for the base case and sensitivity
analysis, I can build one engine and
pass it through different sets of
assumptions. This makes the evolve
stage, which we'll see later, incredibly
simple and error-free. The plan was to have
this function take in all of our
assumptions and return the final cash
flow metrics.
So we have the revenue schedule
represented and the a marketing schedule
represented for years 1 through 10.
Next for the next stage we'll write a
clear plan and move to the implement stage
where we run the analysis function.
so I'll walk you through its logic. One
is the pro-forma calculations. The
calculation first loops from year 1 to
10 and each year it calculates a  mini-pro-forma
income statement. It takes
revenue
subtract the cost of goods sold,
marketing, labor, rent, and depreciation
for the finding for the to find the
earnings before interest in taxes or
EBIT.
And second
is taxes in OFC.
It then calculates taxes on the EBIT
to get net operating profit after tax or
NOPAT.
By adding back the non-cash depreciation
charge, we get our annual operating cash
flow.
Third
is our zero year 0 to year 10. this
model then handles our nonoperating cash
flow. In year zero, it sets the cash
flow to a neg to negative 12.5 million,
which is the 12 million dollar
investment plus the 500,000 for working
capital.
And number four is terminal value. In
year 10, it adds the $500,000
dollar working capital recovery and
critically
the after tax salvage value. Since the 3
million salvage value is fully taxed at
25% the after tax proceeds is precedes
our 2.25 million.
And
another the fifth one is to calculate
the final metrics. Finally, we use this
to complete our 11-year stream of cash
free flow. The function uses the numpy
financial library to calculate the
projects MPV,
RR and profitability index.
Now for
the fourth stage is validate.
here to run the analysis function
using our base case assumption to get
the primary answer. As you can see from
the terminal output, our base case
results
are
Well, as you can see, our terminal
output for the base case results are the
MPV is 3 million,
a little over 3 million and the IRR is 11.99%
and the profitability index is 1.4.
this this decision rule is met. The
MPV is positive and the 11.99%
IRR is comfortably above the 8.5% WACC.
This section also calculates the payback
periods. The simple pay payback is 2.6
years. More importantly, the discounted
payback period is 3.02
years. Meaning the project pays back its
initial investment in today's dollar is
just over three years.
Now for the evolve stage where we use
our model to answer the what if
questions. 
we tested our decision first. I tested a
20% reduction in revenue. The output for
the scenario is very concerning. The NPV
drops to a negative 1.85 million and the
IRR falls to 6.55%
which is below our 8.5 hurdle rate. This
tells us the project is highly sensitive
to its revenue forecast.
second I tested the WACCC
itself. At a lower WACCC
of 6.5%
the MPV improves to 4.3 million and at a
higher WACCC of 10.5%
the MPV is still positive at 1.97
million.
This analysis shows that
the project is far more sensitive to
achieving its sales target rather than
the small changes of its cost capital.
And then finally for the reflect
stage where I complete my
recommendation, my final decision is
to accept the project. the base
case financial analysis is strong. It
creates over three million in value for
the firm and offers a return of nearly
3.5%
above the cost of capital. However, this
acceptance must be qualified as the
evolve stage demonstrated the project's
success is critically dependent on
achieving its revenue target. at a
20% shortfall would make the value
destroy value destroying project.
Therefore, my final recommendation is to
accept the project contingent on
management's high confidence in the
revenue and growth forecast. the
driver process was essential. It
provided not only a single number but a
disciplined workflow for planning to
implement and most importantly to risk
analysis which gave a more complete
respon and responsible
managerial answer. Thank you.

Answer: Hi guys. So in this video I'm going to be walking through uh my capital budgeting and analysis for um session 10's assignment in session 10 assignment proposed Starbucks grocery roy and flagship store investment. Um I'll be using the driver framework to guide the entire workflow which is define, represent, implement, validate, evolve and reflect. Um I'm going to re reference each of the Python code cells uh as I'm as I move through the analysis. Um and these Python code uh cells were created using the help of Gemini. Um and so yeah, let's start with the uh the driver process. And to start this, I'm going to need to do the uh define and discover stage. So in this stage my goal is to clearly understand the business problem uh that Starbucks is facing the decision criteria and the financial and uh modeling work needed. So yeah, Starbucks is considering a 12 million dollar investment in a note in a new roster and flagship store located in a hightraic premium downtown site. The project lasts 10 years and we need to assess whether the project creates shareholder value. Starbucks uh WACCC is 8.5% which becomes our hurdle rate. Uh we've been provided detailed revenue projections, cost structure, depreciation assumptions, taxes, working capital needs, and a $3 million terminal value. Um but this als the the assignment also requires uh calculating year-by-year operating cash flows depreciation tax yields adjusted uh free cash flows net present value internal rate of return payback period discounted payback period profitability index or PI uh sensitivity analysis revenue minus 20%. um a scenario analysis and an ultimate accept/rejection recommendation strategic and non-financial factors. Um yeah, the most critical requirement of the define and discover stage is um that this must be completed before implementation. So here I'm I was just um clarifying what the business needed and then um uh which is that Starbucks must decide whether this roaster investment generates returns above WACCC and supports strategic goals such as brand visibility and long-term market uh presence. Yeah, that completes the define and discover stage. Um but yeah, in this so the next stage is represent stage. Um, I'm going to be outlining the analytical approach. Um, and this is, so what I did before I wrote any code was I, uh, broke down what each cell would need. Um, so yeah, let me break down like what the Python code cells what what I was wanting them to represent. Um in cell one I wanted to import the the nump and pandas and encode the financial assumptions the investment amount wcc tax rate depreciation revenue schedule and operating cost structure and working capital. In cell two, I wanted to build a a full revenue and cost schedule um which lays out revenue by year, cost of goods sold, uh labor, rent and utilities, marketing depreciation, uh EBIT, taxes, and net operating profit or after tax. Um and then cell three, I converted profits into operating cash flows. I computed depreciation tax shield, operating cash flow, subtracted um capex, add working capital changes. I added terminal value and WC recovery in year 10. Um and then in cell four I uh I it included um the the reusable functions for net present value, internal rate of return, payback period, discounted payback, profitability uh index and then in in cell five um was the sensitivity analysis revenue minus 20%. So I recompeted cash flows in a downside scenario. And then um in cell six I calculated net present value at WACCC of 6.5% 8.5% and 10.5% plus highmid low revenue scenarios. And then in um cell seven um it create we created a plot graph for presentation clarity. Um but yeah, that's for um for for represent stage. It's about structuring the work before writing any of the actual code, which is why I was outlining all seven cells and not fully explaining it right now. Um yeah, now we can start with the implement stage. So I I'll walk through the implementations and reference the actual code cells. So in cell one uh I just imported and uh made some and used some of the assumptions. Uh here I set up all the the base parameters. Initial investment of 12 uh million revenue for for years uh 1 through 10 cost percentages uh depreciation straight line over 10 years the the tax rate uh working capital. So yeah, this cell really establishes every variable used later. So then um in cell two, this calculates cost of goods sold, uh labor, rent, marketing, uh depreciation, uh EBIT, taxes, and uh no PIT. Uh this builds uh the operating foundation for cash flows. Um and then cell three uh converts operating profit to free cash flow. This cell adds back depreciation, subtracts um capital exponentials and working capital in year zero and adds terminal values plus working capital recovery in year 10. It produces an array of free cash flows for all 11 periods. And then in um cell four um we used it to uh you using the cash flow from the previous cell I computed net present value at the uh 8.5%. Um and then uh internal rate of return payback period which looks at cumulative uh cash flows discounted payback uh using discounted cumulative cash flow and profitability index which is a prof uh present value benefits divided by investment. And then cell five was a revenue minus the 20%. uh this recalculates every cash flow and lower uh revenues and outputs a uh a new net present value and internal rate of return. This test uh downside vulnerability and then in cell six um I computed net present value at 6.5% 8.5% and 10.5%. I also you I also include best uh base and worst revenue cases. Uh this shows margin of safety and then in cell seven um you can see the the this cell plots cash flows over time in a sensitivity chart. Uh this completes the implementation stage. And then next uh let's validate and so in this stage I confirm whether the results align with the the financial in intuition. So, um, in cell four, um, the net present value at 8.5% should be strongly positive. That's consistent with a project generating c high cash flow relative to its, uh, $12 million cost. Uh, the internal rate of return exceeds the WACC. Another, uh, green light, uh, payback, uh, occurs relatively year early for a 10-year project. and discounted payback is is still acceptable. Um in cell five uh the revenue minus 20% uh scenario produces a significantly lower net present value. However, however, the project may still remain uh viable depending on the exact numbers. Um and then in cell 6 WACC uh sensitivity shows the project retains positive net present value even if discount rates rise which validates uh robustness. Uh the visualization in cell 7 um shows steady cash inflows and strong terminal year recovery. Uh all results appear reasonable and internally consistent with uh and align with typical Starbucks unit economics. So uh that's the validate uh model. Um and then evolve in the evolve stage I think about uh this analysis to uh to other corporate analysis uh um uh I analysize uh generalized to the uh other corporate uh finance workflows. So this template can easily evolve into a Starbucks wide capital allocation model, real options model, uh simulation framework using Monte Carlo ranges, a portfolio, a portfolio level return optimization tool. Um yeah, the structure related in cells 1 through 7 make it modular and reusable for other dis uh questionary uh investments across retail, hospitality and food service sectors. So we're reflecting on this assignment which is the reflect stage. Um the driver framework helped to keep this analysis structured and prevented me from jumping directly into coding before uh understanding a problem. The biggest insight is how critical in incremental uh cash flow indication is not accounting profit but actual free cash flow. Another takeaway is that net present value and uh internal rate of return are useful but sensitivity and scenario analysis reveal the true risk of profile. Um yeah most importantly strategic uh considerations such as uh brand enhancement experiential stores competitive presence and optionality often create intangible values uh beyond pure cash flow modeling. Starbucks flagship stores have marketing marketing value that doesn't fully show up in net present value. Overall, the project reinforced both technical modeling skills and strategic financial thinking. Yeah, that concludes the full driver walkthrough, the implementation, the financial evaluation and the uh investment recommendations supported by quantitative and strategic analysis. Um yeah, thanks for watching guys.
