Answer: All right. Hello there. I'm Joe Dragoni and this is my um se session 10 um management 310 assignment. Um doing the cost of capital analysis. Um so our assignment overview looking at the overview here. We're evaluating Starbucks's proposed flagship roaster that requires a $12 million upfront outlay and is and is expected to operate for 10 years. where you can use the 8.5% weighted average cost of capital um that Starbucks has as the hurdle rate to determine whether the project creates value and to recommended an accept or reject decision supported by driver documentation. So some of the parameters that are given to us here um we have an initial investment of $12 million which in uh involved building of the building equipment and training uh for the people working in this roaster um and it depreciates um over 10 years straight line. So, it's got a 10 year useful life. We got a working capital, $500,000 deployed at launch, and it'll be recovered in year 10. $8 million of revenue in year 1, $11 million of revenue um from years 2 to 5, and then $9 million from years 6 to10. Um so, yeah. Then, operating costs, we got the cost of goods sold being 40% of revenue. Labor being 2.5 million a year fixed. Rent and utilities $800,000 a year, which is fixed. marketing starts at um 300,000 uh or yeah 300,000 in year one and then only 100,000 a year um thereafter. So that one will also be fixed but it starts at.3 and then fixed at 0.1 thereafter till year 10. Then we get 25% corporate uh tax rate and a terminal value of $3 million at the end of year 10. So we'll focus our analysis on producing a transparent cash flow model, the core capital budgeting metrics, sensitivity tests which do the implementation stage and an executive ready recommendation. So looking in our into our driver framework that we'll use for this uh first stage being define and discover. Our goal is that we want to see if this project will earn a return greater than the cost of the funds used to finance it. Um so we must determine if the roster generates a net present value greater than zero. Um, so it must be positive and we must focus on the whack hurdle rate. Um, which is the 8.5% weighted average cost of capital that Starbucks has. Um, and then just some other basic information to go over. Um, if the net present value is greater than zero, this means the project covers all costs, pays back the investors their required 8.5% return and generates extra value on top. So the goal um there we would accept the goal or accept the recommendation. And then if the net present value is negative that means the project destroys shareholder value even if it generates positive accounting profit. So we would reject the project in this case. So to to build the net present value model we must isolate the free cash flows. Um and those components include um the cost incurred um at time zero or the day of the start of the project. So that being the 12 million $12 million for the building equipment and training which is our capital expenditure. the 500,000 required for the inventory and cash on hand which is our working capital and um we would we would observe these as negative values since this money is going out and so the negative cash flows at the start of the project. Um revenues we already talked about having $8 million in year 1, $11 million from years 2 to 5 and $9 million from years 6 to 10. Um and then operating expenses we got the cost of goods sold which is variable because it's 40% of the year's revenue. Um then the fixed costs of labor and rent and utilities. Um the marketing of three million or 300,000 in year one. And then 100,000 for years 2 to 10 which is which will be fixed after year 1. And then also we must consider depreciation expense um which is the initial investment minus the salvage book value um over the 10ear useful life. So it will be calculated as $1.2 million a year. Um but this is a non-cash expense but will still lower taxable income. So it must be noted. And then looking at our tax shield, we must apply the 25% tax rate to the earnings before interest taxes or EBIT. Um, and that'll be an outflow. And then looking at terminal value adjustments, we're selling for $3 million um at the end of the investment, but there's also tax. Um, so 3 million times 25% tax is 75 million. So our net cash inflow uh at the end of the 10 years will be 2.25 million. Um, and then we want to calculate the net present value at year 10. and determine if that will overcome our hurdle rate of 8.5%. And see if there's value generated from this project. So now moving down to the represent stage where we actually calculate the cash flows for each year. Um we want to visualize the flow of money for this 10-year investment. Um and determine if this project creates value. Um yeah, we'll create a cash flow timeline for the 10 years of the investment. So we talk we talked about depreciation a little bit already. It's the cost basis minus the salvage value over the useful life. So, like we talked about already, $12 million, um, which is the initial check written minus the salvage value of zero over the 10 year useful life is $1.2 million. Um, our salvage value here is zero for tax purposes because when companies assume the asset loses all its value in 10 years, they get a larger tax deduction. So, that would actually be better for us. Um, and this is better for net present value because of time value of money. Um, like we've learned already, um, saving cash today is better than saving cash in 10 years due to factors like inflation and other things like that. So, looking at our 10-year investment cash flow schedule, um, in year zero or the day the project starts, we talked about already um, having negative 12.5 million in outflows due to the, um, paying for the building, equipment, and training, which is 12 million, and the 500,000 working capital for inventory, etc. Um, so 12.5 million out of our pockets. In year one for the investment, but in year two in or year zero, we lose the 12.5 million. In year 1 is when we actually start to generate some cash inflows. So we have the revenue of 8 million in year 1. Um, but we have to subtract our operating expenses. So cost of goods sold up3.2, labor and utilities, labor, rent, and utilities -2.5, million800,000. and then the year 1 marketing of300,000. So 6.8 million in operating expenses and then calculating our taxes, it would be zero at this point. Um, and then we got the 8 million in revenue minus the operating expenses minus the 1.2 million depreciation. So that shows that we have zero earnings before taxes and interest. So there's nothing to be taxed. So this shows our cash flows. The 8 million minus the 6.8 million operating expenses is 1.2 2 million in year 1. And then from years 2 to 5, uh, revenue is 11 million at this point. Cost of goods sold of the the 40% of 11 million is 4.4 million. So we lose that. Um, the labor and rent stay the same. Marketing is 100,000, which is it goes down. Um, so we have $7.8 million in operating expenses, which increases. Um, but our revenue also increases. So calculating the earnings before taxes and interest gives us $2 million which is just the 11 million revenue minus the operating expenses of 7.8 million minus the depreciation. Um so that's income that can be taxed. So applying the tax rate to that um we pay $500,000 in taxes. So, our cash flows is the earnings before income or interest in taxes minus the 500,000 in taxes is 1.5 million uh for our free cash flows from years 2 to 5 as well as adding back the depreciation that we took off since it's a non-cash expenditure. So, it would be 2.7 million of cash flows there. And then looking at year 6 to9, the revenue goes down to 9 million. um calculating the cost of goods sold, labor, rent, and marketing again to give us 7 million in operating expenses. Then taking then we get the earnings before interest in taxes of 800,000. Tax that by 20 or multiply that by 25% to get the taxed income that we have to pay and then we get the free cash flows of um 1.8 million. And then looking at this last year, year 10, um our exit year where we generate the bulk of our earnings, our um incomes, we have the free cash flows 4.8 million from the year before. The recovery of the working capital, which is $500,000. Our investment is fully depreciated as we talked about with the salvage value being zero. And then looking at the terminal value here, it's the sale price of $3 million which we sold it for minus the tax which would be 25% of that 3 million which is 750,000 gives us 2.25 million of for the terminal value. So our cash flow is the operating free cash flow is 1.8 million plus the recovery of the working capital which is 500,000 plus our terminal value which is 4.55 million. So that's where the bulk of our cash inflows come from is this um last year our exit year. So we can see that this project is quite backloaded. So now to calculate the present value of this it's the 4.55 million over the 1.085 which is our whack our discount rate whack calculation um raised to the 10year period is 2.1 2.01 million. So obviously less than what we think of it or what we calculated as here. Um and then just look at the net present value sum of the present value from each year which we'll show in the implement stage more in detail is 2.69 million. So that will be our represent stage. So now we move down to the implement stage where we actually can apply all this information or have Gemini help us to create this these calculations automatically as well as calculations for the um what else did we make calculations for? um the discount payback period, civil payback period, profitability index, and then the sensitivity analysis for the reduced revenue and the whack um as well as helping to create our recommendation. So looking down at this we have all the code made here and then we can run it real quick and then we'll see from here going up to the first part the comprehensive financial model our base case whack is 8.5% as we saw already and looking at all of the cash flows um that we calculated already um like we see in year zero we have the negative 12.5 million and then we get those same cash flow amounts that we calculated in the represent stage and then it shows us the present value of those investments um as a percentage of what the actual cash flow is. So in year one the present value is 92% of that um the present value 84 85% 78 72 it goes the present value decreases as time goes on which aligns with our time value of money knowledge that we already have and then or that's the PV factor rather and then the present value we can see it um reflect that same information that we've already learned here. So our total NPV which is the sum of all these present values is 2.69 million. So then looking at some of the core investment metrics that we talked about um the internal rate of return is 12.84% which is greater than our target which would mean we would accept the project here in this case got a profitability index of 1.22 simple payback period of 5.3 and discounted payback of 8.2. Um so like we said we will go more in detail in this in the next stage. Um but now looking down at the sensitivity analysis for our discount rate um as we test out the different whack amounts um our base case here of 8.5%. Shows that we would accept the project and as the whack decreases um a lower hurdle rate to jump over it increases the net present value. So a hurdle rate of 6% gives us a whack of 4.66 or a net present value of 4.66 which is very good for us. It's very high number. So we would accept it there. And then conversely as the whack goes up closer to double digit percentages 10% 11 12 13 14 we start to get into dangerously low territory. um at 13% is when we get into the negatives which is when we would start to reject because if net present value is not positive then we would not want to we would not want to accept the project. So then also looking at the revenue scenarios in a different sensitivity analysis um looking at the impact of a drop in revenue also in an increase of revenue um like we said we don't have in this scenario we get all of our revenue our net present value is 2.69 69. So we'd accept the project there. We'll drop in 5% would decrease our net present value, but it's still greater than zero. So we could accept it. But as we get into the -10s, negative 20s, losing revenue, um this would cause our net present value to be negative. So we would end up rejecting the project. And then same as if we go if we go up to 10% here, gaining even more revenue. Obviously, we would want to accept. So I also created um some tables, some graphs that show this the correlation between net present value and the whack as well as the change in revenue. As we can see there's negative correlation between whack and net present value as it decreases um as the yeah as the net present or as the whack rather increases the net present value decrease and then as the revenue change increases. So as we get more revenue our net present value will increase which actually makes a lot of sense when we think about it. So then moving down to the validation stage here. Um like we talked about simple single payback period is roughly 5 years and 3 months to recover the initial cash outlife. So this is relatively long for a retail investment like Starbucks but is still acceptable for us. Our discounted payback period is 8.2 years which means that the project does not break even in value until in value terms until late in the cycle. So we see the value is uh backloaded like we talked about already because we get lots of our value from the exit in year 10. Um if the lease is terminated early, the project will likely destroy value. So that is a risk to keep in mind with this project. If we decide to bail early on it, we will not capture our full value and we'll likely even lose some money. Then our profitability index is 1.22 times. So for every dollar Starbucks invests in the roaster, it generates $122 in present value. So that is acceptable uh as we're generating more money um the more we invest at least at this stage. Then our sensitivity robustness check like we talked about we done we did that already. um the negative correlation between NPV and whack. Um the reduction in revenue would also see reduction in NPV um and it gets into the negative point. So there's a positive correlation between these two and um looking at a terminal value check we calculate the terminal value in the implement stage and as well as the represent stage at year 10. So that $4.55 million in year 10 that we got out of it accounts for nearly 45% of our total net present value. So we are highly sensitive to that exit assumption. Um and this is because specialized equipment like huge coffee roasters or roasteries that we that Starbucks would implement here often has very low resale value and retail fitouts usually have zero value after 10 years. Um if the terminal value becomes zero, we lose 2.25 $.25 million uh of act after after tax inflow in year 10 and the present value of that loss is roughly a million dollar. So losing a million is very unappealing. Um so we do not want that terminal value to drop to zero. And then this would also cause the net present value to drop from 2.69 million to 1.69 million losing our million dollars as we talked about already. Um and it's still safe. The net present value is still greater than zero but it's less attractive to the shareholders. So they would likely not recommend the project knowing what we could have had. And then the operating leverage check, we assume that cost of goods sold is a perfect 40% of revenue. But in reality, they don't fall as fast as revenue does. Um so if revenues drop to $6 million in a bad year, the labor and rent, they will remain fixed. Um so the margin is significantly reduced as we're still paying these fixed costs. Um but we're not making as much revenue to cover those costs. Um and then looking at the what the break even sales volume is. That's if the break even is point is too close to our forecasted sales. The project is operationally fragile. Um so luckily we're not too close to that point but that's just another leverage check. If like if we lost our revenue then it would get us closer to the forecasted sales which would make the project be less appealing since there's a lot more risk involved there. Now moving down to the evolve stage. um looking at some applications of NPV and other concepts. So this has been overarching concept the present value time value of money um in all the sections that we've done in management 310 so far. So like cost of capital in section 9 real estate and mortgages in section five time value of money was specifically centered on present value net present value calculation um and many more if not all. Um and then just some like actual real life scenarios where this could be used. Um merchants and acquisitions um using capital budgeting on a massive scale um instead of buying a coffee roastery this would mean Starbucks would buyer would buy a entire company or like a coffee bean farm or something like that. So the decision rule that we would have to think about in this case would be calculating the net present value of the existing cash flows or the present value of our existing cash flows or our target plus the present value of our synergies which is the cost savings or revenue boost that wouldn't exist independently and then we subtract our cost which would be the price paid for that company or that farm. Um this can also be applied to customer lifetime value or CLV where we treat marketing spend expenditures as an investment and not just as an expense. So our cash inflows would be our margin per customer times the retention rate and our hurdle would be the discount rate um reflecting the risk of the customer churning. So that would apply whack concepts in that as well. So if our customer lifetime value is greater than our customer acquisition cost or CAC um which is very similar to the whack for capital budgeting then we would determine the market campaign has a positive net present value and then also looking at leasing versus buying which goes along with the session five real estate and mortgages that we talked about a few weeks ago. A company like Starbucks decides whether to own a building or to lease it. So in the case of the roaster looking at owning or leasing this building um which creates more value for us um we have a couple options. Option A to buy pay $12 million up front and benefit from depreciation tax shields and residual value at the end or to lease the building pay $0 upfront and pay the annual rent which is taxdeductible. Um, so the net present value of leasing versus buying would be avoiding the rent payments minus the purchase price plus the depreciation tax shield and see which one provides more value for us. So those would be some of the applications we could use um of the capital budgeting and net present value stages. And then going down to the reflection stage, the last stage of the driver framework. Um, as we talked about already, net present value is the overarching concept not only in this class but also in all of the business finance world. Um, and it's a concept many businesses face every day. So, just reinforcing that idea and getting me to think even more about that is another thing I reflected on during this journey. Some other key insights taken away from net present value calculation and capital budgeting. Um, we learned that net income does not equal cash flow. As year one, our model showed zero net income. Um, then the earnings before interest in taxes. Um, the business generated $1.2 million in cash. Um, because we added back the depreciation costs, we took away even though they're non-cash expenditures, we still accounted for them in our financial statements. Um, accounting profits include non-cash fantasies like depreciation. Um, and valuation must be based on money you can actually spend or return to share shareholders. Um another takeaway that we took or that we another insight that we took away rather um we had the 8.5 8.5% whack which represents the opportunity cost of money being spent on investment that can't be returned to shareholders. So kind of weighing the options there. If a project can't beat the whack, we are effectively stealing value from investors even if the project makes a profit. So that's just something else we need to consider how much money we're really spending and if it's worth it um based on our rate of return compared to our whack terminal value. Um we discover that nearly 45% of the project's value came from year 10 which was the exit or selling our company or the roster rather. Um and long-term projects depend on this exit. Um a slight error in this calculation can flip a decision from accept to reject. So we always really need to scrutinize the final year and make sure that our calculations are actually accurate. As for the sensitivity analysis, um we saw the negative correlation between net present value and whack as well as the positive correlation between the revenue and the net present value. Um and then we saw this framework of spending money now and get risky money later applies to everything which is aka being universally applicable. Um, and the net present value framework is the universal language of business business viability. Um, whether that be in mergers and acquisitions or leasing versus buying a building, all of these business decisions, uh, in one way or another rely on the net present value framework. And then lastly, uh, looking at our executive recommendation, um, we would accept this project because we saw the net present value being greater than the hurdle rate. um or in other words the internal rate of return exceeding the whack of 8.5%. So the project is financially profitable or positive and profitable as the net present value of 2.69 million over 10 years. Um the net present value is 2.69 over 10 years but it's operationally fragile as it relies on high revenue volume. Um it's got positive operating cash flows which begin in year one with that $1.2 million and continue Yeah, the $1.2 million inflow and they continue through year 10. Some key risk factors we had to look at as well is that because we had the $3.4 million in fixed costs um through the sensitivity analysis, we saw the 20% drop in revenue eliminates nearly all of that shareholder value um since the net present value is less than zero there. Um and the 45% of net present value derived from the year 10 exit um shows that um if the location can't be sold or subleasased favorably in a decade, the returns diminish. So we really again have to put emphasis on that last year and make sure that we will be actually be able to take away this value. So the roaster shouldn't be treated as just a coffee shop but as a capitalized marketing expense. And there are all these different costs that we need to consider while we're looking at this decision. So that is my session 10 driver framework um assignment looking at the cost of capital. Answer:
Discover
The DRIVER framework provides a structured way to approach complex investment decisions, and it can be applied directly to capital budgeting problems with multiple cash flow stages. To illustrate this, imagine a company called UrbanCharge, which installs fast electric-vehicle charging stations across major cities. UrbanCharge is considering a $40 million investment to deploy 300 new chargers, but management is uncertain whether the project will truly create long-term value, especially given rising interest rates and unpredictable cash flows. The strategic question is whether the company should commit such a large upfront investment without confidence that the project will generate sufficient returns. Framing this uncertainty is the starting point of the DRIVER approach.
Represent 
The next step is to represent the problem using clean and organized financial inputs. UrbanCharge estimates that the project will require a $40 million initial investment plus $2 million in upfront working capital. Operating cash flows are expected to be $6 million annually for the first three years, followed by $10 million annually from years four through seven. At the end of year seven, the company expects to recover the working capital and receive a $4 million salvage value, bringing the final-year terminal value to $6 million. The appropriate discount rate for evaluating the project is a WACC of 10.5 percent. Structuring the information this way creates a clear foundation for applying NPV, which depends entirely on how well the cash flows are organized across time.
Implement 
Once the project is represented in financial terms, the next step is to implement the analysis by calculating the NPV using the company's WACC. Each future cash flow is discounted back to the present at 10.5 percent to account for the time value of money and the risk of the project. In class, we emphasized that NPV is the most reliable measure of value creation because it produces a dollar amount that directly reflects whether a project meets or exceeds its required return. When the cash flows are discounted and added together, the present value of the inflows is approximately $47.2 million. After subtracting the combined initial outlay of $42 million for investment and working capital, the project's NPV is roughly $5.2 million. Since this number is positive, the project creates value and exceeds the company's required return.
Validate 
After calculating NPV, it is important to validate the results by testing the sensitivity of the assumptions. UrbanCharge needs to consider scenarios in which EV adoption slows, interest rates increase, or installation costs exceed expectations. If operating cash flows in years four through seven fall from $10 million to $8 million, or if the WACC increases from 10.5 percent to 12 percent, the NPV remains positive but becomes smaller. In more severe downside cases, such as a WACC of 15 percent combined with weaker cash flows, the NPV can turn negative. This type of validation helps the company understand where the project is strong and where it is vulnerable, reinforcing the idea that financial decisions depend not just on a single NPV number but also on the stability of that number across different conditions.
Execute 
Once the analysis has been validated, the company can execute a decision. Given that the project shows a positive NPV and remains viable under most realistic scenarios, UrbanCharge should proceed with the investment. However, it should also take steps to reduce risk, such as locking in long-term financing before interest rates rise further, implementing a phased rollout to control installation costs, and monitoring early-year performance to confirm demand projections. Execution connects financial analysis to real operational strategy, which is the goal of corporate finance decision-making.
Reflect 
Finally, reflecting on the entire process shows how the DRIVER method supports clear, organized thinking in complex situations. Instead of jumping straight to the math, DRIVER forces decision-makers to define the problem, structure the information, perform the analysis, challenge the results, and connect the findings back to strategy. This is the same approach we used in class: DRIVER turns a messy real-world project into a transparent and logical decision supported by financial evidence. The broader takeaway is that when a project involves multiple stages, uncertain cash flows, or high initial costs, DRIVER helps ensure that nothing is overlooked and that the final decision is grounded in value creation.

Hello, my name is Alexander Emenhiser and this is my video for the session 10 assignment. It is currently Sunday, November 23rd, and I am in the 12:30 section of management 310. Our session today will primarily focus on capital budgeting and investment decisions. We will be doing that by conducting a full cost of analysis, cost of capital analysis. We're going to be doing this by evaluating Starbucks's proposed flagship roaster that requires $12 million upfront outlay and is expected to out operate for 10 years. We will be using an 8 1/2 WACC as our hurdle rate to determine whether the project generates value and to recommend an accept/reject decision which we will support using the driver framework. There are several parameters as we can see here that we will discuss later in the session and that we must keep an eye on. We want to produce a transparent uh cash flow model, core capital budgeting metrics, sensitivity tests and an executive ready recommendation. There are several financial analysis requirements which we will all answer throughout this session. As with other sessions, I have used the assistance of AI to help generate all the hard coding of our Python here. And I'm going to be confirming that with my own work and analysis. Like before, I will also continue to use the driver framework of learning to help guide my work. So, let's begin with our analysis of Starbucks. So the first step of our driver framework as always is to define and discover. In the define and discover stage, my objective was to thoroughly understand the financial decision facing Starbucks and identify all of the information required to build a reliable and defensive valuation of this model. Before touching any code, I started by clearly defining the central question. Does this proposed flagship roaster create enough econ economic value to justify a $12 million upfront investment? From there, I mapped out every component that would influence our financial decision that included confirming the 10-year project life, the $500,000 in working capital needed at the onset and recovered in the final year. the full revenue schedule provided in the case and each category of the operating costs such as cost of goods sold, labor, rent, and utilities, and marketing expenditures. I also noted that the entire $12 million investment must be depreciated straight line over the project's life, which directly affects taxable income and the depreciation tax shield. Our assignment here also specifies the a 25% corporate tax rate and a $3 million terminal value

at in year 10. Both of which must be incorporated into the cash flow model. As part of our uh discovery, I ensured I fully understood the financial framework guiding our analysis. This project must be evaluated using the Starbucks's 8 12 weighted average cost of capital which serves as our hurdle rate and represents the opportunity cost of investing capital elsewhere. That makes the discounting process which is the interpretation of our net present value the cornerstone of our decision. The our our session will also require us to generate a complete set of capital budgeting metrics including net present value, internal rate of return, discounted and simple payback periods and the profit profitability index. To meet the technical requirements, I needed a model that could run sensitivity tests, specifically a 20% reduction in revenue and changes in the WACC of plus or minus 2%. Knowing this upfront was essential because it meant I had to design the code so that all assumptions were parameter parameterized, transparent and easy to modify. Finally, during this stage, I outlined the analytical approach that it would take to ensure the work aligned with our driver framework. That meant planning a clear clear flow from defining the problem to structuring the model to implementing and validating results and ultimately translating the quantitative outputs into a management ready recommendation for Starbucks. Spending the time to map out the entire problem in the define and discover stage ensured that once I moved into the represent and implement stages, the work was organized, grounded in financial logic and fully aligned with both the R session assignments and the broader principles of a discipline decision making and capital budgeting. After defining the problem and identifying every parameter as we talked about here that the model needed to incorporate, the next stage of our driver framework of learning is to represent. In this phase, my goal was to translate the conceptual understanding of the project into a structured analytical plan before writing any code. I began by outlining the full financial model on paper, which shows a year-by-year cash flow schedule covering years 0 through 10. This included mapping out how revenues would differ across the three phases of projects, year 1, years 2 through 5, and years 6 through 10, and pairing these revenues with their corresponding cost structures, cost of goods sold at 40%. Consistent labor expenses of 2.5 million, fixed rent utilities of 800,000, and declining marketing spending after the first year. I also identified where depreciation needed to appear, making sure the $12 million investment was allocated evenly over 10 years since this directly affects the EBIT taxes and ultimately the project's after tax operating cash flow. Additionally, I noted that that both working capital development or deployment in year zero and recovery in year 10 needed to be incorporated as well as the $3 million terminal value which must be taxed appropriately in the final year. During the represent stage, I also designed the structure for how the capital budgeting metrics would be calculated once the cash flows were built. This included specifying where discounting would occur to compute net present value and how the internal rate of return would be derived and how both simple and discounted payback periods would be measured from cumulative cash flows. I also estimated the logic for calculating the prof profitability index by dividing the present value of our future inflows by the present value of the initial outflow. Equally important, I built the structure for the required sensitivity analyses, which is one scenario reducing all revenues by 20% and another by adjusting the discount rate by plus or minus 2% around Starbucks's 8 12 WACC. By planning these components up front, I ensure that the Python script would be modular, parameter driven, and easy to adapt. Finally, our represent stage included determining what outputs should be generated to support the executive recommendation. This meant planning clear numerical tables, organized metrics, and visualizations of cash flow and sensitivity impacts so that the results would not only be accurate but also easy to interpret in a presentation setting. By the end of our represent stage, I had a complete blueprint of the model structure, which is what would be calculated when and how. So that moving into the implement stage would be smooth, efficient and fully aligned with the requirements of our session here. So now we move to that next stage of our driver framework which is implement. And this is where we can first start getting into our code a little bit. So as we see here, we have our define and discover stage. as I was discussing before where we have all of our parameters that I described. Then we had some of these code here as I discussed uh in our represent stage. Each of these we touched on earlier but now our goal is to actually go through more of the code. So, in the implement stage, I transform the conceptual financial model into a fully operational analysis, building a year-by-year projection that computes every relevant cash flow associated with our project.

I began by organizing the key assumptions such as the initial investment, yearly revenues, operating costs, tax rate, expected project life, and discount rate into a structured set of inputs that the model references throughout.

Establishing these assumptions clearly at the beginning ensures the analysis is transparent and allows for quick adjustments during our sensitivity testing. Once the assumptions were set, I constructed a complete financial schedule covering the entire life of the project from the initial investment through the final recovery of working capital in the last year. The schedule starts with topline revenue each year

and

reflecting the expected pattern of sales growth and decline over the project's 10-year horizon. Below the revenue model subtracts major categories of cost such as uh present the percentage based cost of goods sold the fixed labor cost, rent and utilities.

And these cost items are shown explicitly so that anyone reviewing the model can trace exactly how operating profit is formed. Depreciation is then incorporated as a non-cash expense based on the initial investment of net salvage value spread evenly over the life of the project. Including depreciation is important because it affects taxable income and creates a tax shield that later flows into operating cash flows. After subtracting all expenses from revenue, the model computes the yearly operating profit, then applies the corporate tax rate to determine the project's after tax operating income. At that point, depreciation is added back since it's a non-cash to convert uh accounting income into true operating cash flow.

Uh next, our model integrates the timing of investment flows in the initial year. The model records the full cost of equipment as an outflow along with the required increase in working capital. At the end of the final year, the model brings in the expected proceeds from selling the equipment as well as the recovery of working capital. These adjustments ensure that the model captures the complete economic impact of the project from beginning to end. The yearly net cash flows are then discounted back to the present using the firm's cost of capital. Summing these discounted values produces the project's net present value, which becomes the centerpiece of a valuation to provide additional insight. The model also calculates the internal rate of return, the simple and discounted payback periods, and the profitability index. Because relying solely on baseline assumptions can be misleading, I incorporated our sensitivity testing uh directly into the implementation.

Uh the model can adjust revenues downward by 20% to test the impact of weaker demand or shift the discount rate up and down by two percentage points to explore the effects of changing capital costs. For each scenario, the full cash flow schedule is rebuilt and re-evaluated. This produces a new net present value and return metrics that show how fragile or robust the project is under alternative conditions. Finally, I generated visualizations

to support clearer interpretation. One chart displays the project's cash flows over time. And I can actually go down to here to talk about a little bit. So this is our cash flows over time, making it easy to see the size of the project's initial outflow and the pattern of yearly inflows and the surge of recovered value at the end of the project. Our second chart here plots the net present value against the different discount rates to highlight how sensitive the decision is to financing conditions. Together, these visual tools help translate the analysis into intuitive insights that would be easy for an executive to understand.

Overall, our implementation stage takes the abstract structure created in the represent stage and turns it into a working model that produces concrete financial results, documents the project's risk, and supports a defensible recommendation. And we can see all of these things that we talked about here actually come together. So we talked about a lot of this in our represent represent stage, but now we actually implemented it here into our code. So now that we've written the code and talked about, you know, how we came about coming up with the code, uh it's time to now validate our code. And that is the next stage of our driver framework. And this is where we're going to kind of look at and see if it makes sense uh for our outputs. And our goal here is to ensure our capital budgeting model not only calculates the correct number but also accurately represents the economic reality of the proposed Starbucks flagship roaster. First, we confirm that all relevant inflows and outflows are captured in the model. This includes our $12 million initial investment and capital expenditures of 500,000. uh

and deployment near zero and the uh the annual operating cash flow is derived from the EBIT uh minus taxes plus the depreciation tax shield and the terminal inflow in year 10 which combines the $3 million salvage value and the recovery of working capital. The model outputs year-over-year cash flows ranging from 450,000 in year 1 to 1,950,000 in years 2 through 5. And then 1,50,000 in years 6 through 10.

uh with the final year increasing to 4,550,000 to represent the terminal inflow. Discounting these cash flows at Starbucks's 8 and a half WACC produces a net present value of negative1,898,416

as we see here 19 indicating that the project would destroy shareholder value under the base case assumptions. We then evaluated the core capital budgeting metrics. So the internal rate of return of 94.94% is unusually high due to the large terminal inflow which illustrates the potential pitfalls of relying solely on IRR for projects with non-conventional cash flows. the profitability index of.848

uh which is less than one collabor corates the negative NPV suggesting that the project is not a financially efficient use of capital. The simple payback period is roughly nine years, almost the full life of the project, while the discounted payback exceeds the 10-year horizon, showing that the project does not recover its investment in present value terms. These metrics together provide a consistent and robust single signal that the project should be rejected if we ever follow the net present value rule. Next, we then validated the sensitivity of the model to key assumptions. A 20% reduction in revenue leads to a dramatically lower net present value of 7,673,655.77,

showing that the project is highly sensitive to revenue performance. While adjustments in the WACC by plus or minus 2% produce net present values ranging from about $755,000

to two to -2,883,811

demonstrating the moderate sensitivity to the discount rate. These results highlight the fragility of the project's value under adverse scenarios and the reinforce the need for careful revenue forecasting and risk management. Finally, we examine the visual outputs uh generated by the model. And our first graph displays the year-by-year cash flows clearly showing the timing and magnitude of the initial outlay, the steady operating inflows, and the large terminal inflow at the end of year 10. This chart makes visually intuitive to understand how the investment unfolds over time. And our second graph, as I've kind of touched on a little bit before, uh, plots the net present value against the variations in the discount rate, illustrating how the project's value changes with the cost of capital, making it easy to see the net present value remains negative across all reasonable reasonable ranges of the WACC. Together, these graphs not only confirm that the numerical outputs are consistent with financial theory, but also provide a clear executive ready visualization of risk, return, and the timing of cash flows. Overall, our validation stage confirms the model's accuracy uh and accurately incorporates every relevant component which are initial investment, operating cash flows, appreciation, working capital changes, and terminal value. and that the metrics, sensitivity tests, and visualizations collectively support a robust defensible conclusion, which is that the project does not generate economic value at Starbucks's 8 12 WACC, is highly sensitive to revenue performance, and it produces multiple indicators signaling rejection. This thorough validation ensures that the analysis is precise, transparent and fully aligned with both our driver framework and standal standard capital budgeting principles. Now our next stage is the evolve stage of the driver framework where we take the analysis be beyond our basic requirements here and explore how capital budgeting approach can be applied for more broadly to to strategic financial decision-m while the base case evaluation provides a clear accept or reject signal for the Starbucks flagship roaster. The evolved stage emphasizes how the same methodology could guide larger scale corporate investment decisions, portfolio management, and even companywide strategic planning. For instance, the net present value framework we applied here can be scaled to evaluate a series of potential roasterries or other major capital projects, allowing Starbucks's management to systematically compare alternatives, allocate capital efficiency, and prioritize projects that maximize shareholder value. Similarly, sensitivity testing and scenario analyses such as our revenue negative 20% case and the WACCC of plus or minus 2% variations can be expanded into Monte Carlo simulations or full probabilistic forecastes providing richer picture of potential risks and uncertainties across multiple investments. Beyond financial metrics, the evolved stage also encourages consideration of strategic and operational benefits that are more difficult to quantify but may influence the company's decision. For example, while the base case net present value is negative, the roaster could enhance brand visibility, serve as an exper experiential marketing hub, or generate operational learning for Starbucks's supply chain and production innovation. Quantifying these benefits alongside traditional cash flow analysises allows management to integrate both financial and strategic value creation into a comprehensive investment decision framework. The visualizations we produced through yearly cash flow timelines and net present value sensitivity charts also evolve in this stage becoming tools for scenario comparison, risk communication, and executive decision-m by presenting multiple potential outcomes. Clearly, these graphs help management understand not just a single expected net present value, but the full range of possible project values under different assumptions. Ultimately, our evolve stage demonstrates that capital budget budgeting analysises are is not static. It is a flexible tool that can guide ongoing strategic decisions. It reinforces the importance of structured evaluation, transparency of assumptions and scenario testing of both individual project evaluation and broader corporate investment planning. By thinking beyond our parameters here, we see how the same driver frame methodology and disciplined financial modeling can support systematic, repeatable, and defensive decision-making for Starbucks's long-term growth and shareholder value creation. And our final stage of the driver framework is our reflect stage where we take a step back to synthesize the insights gained from our full capital budgeting analysis and consider what they teach us about systematic investment decision-m looking at Starbucks's flagship roaster we see that by care carefully calcul by carefully defining the problem representing the cash flows accurately and implementing a detailed model validating results s through sensitivity analysis and exploring broader applications, we were we are able to make a disciplined evidence-based recommendation. The negative MPV at the firm's WACC, the sub one profitability index, and the sensitivity tests all point towards rejecting the project if evaluated strictly on financial criteria. At the same time, the visualizations, including the year-by-year cash flow chart and the net present value sensitivity plot, provide clarity on the timing, magnitude, and risk of cash flows, reinforcing the quantitative findings while supporting communication with management or shareholders. Reflecting on the broader lessons, we see that disciplined application of net present value and capital budgeting principles allows corporate decision makers to separate strategic narratives from hard financial reality. Our exercise demonstrates the importance of considering not only baseline metrics, but also alternative scenarios, risk exposures, and potential upside from strategic benefits that are harder to quantify, such as brand impact or operational learning. By systematically following the driver framework, we also see how a structured approach from a problem definition to implementation to validation to then strategic evolution ensures that financial analysis is transparent, repeatable, and defensible. This reflection underscores that the skills developed in this analysis, including modeling complex cash flows, testing sensitivity to key assumptions, and visualizing outcomes for decision-m are transferable to evaluating other major investments, guiding portfolio decisions, and ultimately supporting Starbucks's long-term value creation strategy. So, this has been our session 10 assignment. My name is Alexander Emenhiser and have a happy Thanksgiving. Thank you.

Answer:
Hello, this is my submission for the
section six cost of capital analysis
assignment. Today I'll walk through the
driver framework to evaluate the
proposed Starbucks flagship roaster.
The objective is to determine if the $12
million investment creates shareholder
value using the firm's 8.5% whack.
So we begin with the define and
discover phase. Here I've translated the
case constraints into Python variables
to ensure the model is flexible. First
we have the project parameters.
We have a 10-year horizon
discount rate. The whack is set to 8.5%
which is our hurdle rate. Investment you
can see the initial outlay of $12
million and a working capital of 500
grand. revenues. I have defined the
revenue streams $8 million in year one,
increasing to $11 million for years two
through five and stabilizing at $9
million for the remainder.
And then cost. Cost of goods sold are
pegged at 40% of revenue alongside the
fixed labor and rent costs specified in
the case.
Moving on to the represent phase. This
is the logic engine of the analysis.
Rather than hard- coding values, I
created a function called analyze
project. This is critical because it
allows me to pass different arguments,
specifically the revenue factor and the
wax scenario to run sensitivity analysis
later without rewriting code. Inside the
function, I'm modeling the standard free
cash flow formula. First, I calculate
the EBIT
down here
by subtracting the cost of goods sold,
rent, labor, marketing, and depreciation
from revenue. I then apply the 25% tax
rate to get NOAT,
net operating profit after tax. To get
operating cash flow, I added back the
non-cash depreciation charge. And then
finally I subtracted cost
capital expenditures and adjust for
working capital changes specifically the
outflow in year zero and the recovery in
year 10.
I also calculate the terminal value here
applying taxes to gain on sale in
discounting the final cash flows back to
year zero using the numpy financial
library
that's shown down here.
Next is the implement phase. Here I
execute the analyze project
function using the default parameters.
This generates our base case scenario.
The script automatically builds a data
frame containing every line from year 0
through 10, ensuring we have full
visibility
into the incremental cash flows.
Now down to stage V, validate. Looking
at the console output, we can verify the
model's integrity.
Go down to the output
right here. Cash flow as you can see the
negative cash flow in year zero
representing the investment positive
cash flow beginning in year one.
The metrics the MPV is approximately
$2.7 million.
Because this is greater than zero, the
project is expected to cover its cost of
capital and actually add value. The IRRa
is set to 12.84%
which exceeds the 8.5% whack. And the
discounted payback period is 8.21 years,
meaning we recover our risk adjusted
capital well before the project ends,
which is 10 years.
stage E
evolve. However, a base case is rarely
enough. In the evolve phase, I perform
sensitivity analysis to test the
project's robustness. And I ran three
additional scenarios here
down here.
Revenue risk a 20% reduction in
topline revenue. Cost of capital risk
increasing the whack to 10.5%.
and cost of capital opportunity by
decreasing the whack to 6.5%.
And shown with these charts looking at
the visualizations, the top chart shows
the healthy positive cash flows in the
green against the initial outlay in red
and the bottom chart is the critical
decision tool. You can see that even if
the whack fluctuates by 2% the MPV
remains positive. However, looking at
the revenue minus 20% bar, the MPV turns
negative approximately negative $1.3
million
uh or $3 million. This indicates the
project is highly sensitive to sales
volume. If the flagship store fails to
drive traffic, value will be destroyed.
And finally, the reflect stage.
Based on the quantitative analysis, I
recommend accepting this project.
Financially, the base case MPV of $2.7
million and the IRRa of 13.5% offer a
solid buffer above the cost of capital.
Strategically a flagship roaster, this
investment likely offers intangible
benefits such as brand equity and
product innovation that aren't fully
captured in the cash flows. However, the
acceptance is conditional on the
confidence in the revenue projects.
Given the sensitivity to the 20% revenue
drop, management should prioritize
marketing effectiveness in year one to
ensure that sales targets are met. And
yeah, thank you.

And what I want to do here is just take a step back and synthesize or uh summarize all the information that was provided to us to just have a stable platform to begin our work on or analysis. So we have the capital investment at the year zero of actually you know setting the project up or buying it is $12 million. Then you have again as I said the working capital of 500,000. And this is interesting as we also have a depreciation method uh which is straight line over 10 years. And I'll be going through over this um in a bit, but what it is essentially saying is that the project or equipment that we have is going to be depreciated over 10 years by a set amount each year um to a terminal value of $3 billion at year 10. Then operating data, we have again 40% of revenue, fixed operating costs, marketing cost, and here's the clear revenue schedule. So for the first year we have $8 million um of revenue coming in. For the next four years we have $1 million and for the final 5 years we have 9 $9 million. So this kind of reflects the um different stages. So um how do I say different stages in terms of setting you know the slow growth when the equipment building or the whole setup is um initiated then we have the stable growth at $1 million and then the final decline growth around $9 million. But this is just a hypo hypo uh a expected or assumption that we're making that this presents the growth trend of how the revenue will change. Now let us move to the implement stage. Now here we have a lot of different equations to go through. Um so let's just get straight into it. So we have all the information from the represent stage already here and there are different values that we want to uh calculate. We have operation operating costs. We have depreciation, the earnings before income taxes applied. We have the actual taxes, the net operating profit after tax. We have uh many more um cash flows, a terminal cash flow and capital investments, but we'll look into it later. So the free cash flow is the capex at year 0 plus the net worth change at year 0 as well. Now the annual depreciation as I said is the same appreciate uh amount being depreciated each year. So you see the project year is 10 years and then capex initial value is from right here. So additionally some of the other costs that we will be using or uh factors you'll be using is the uh earnings before income tax. So this is given by revenue minus operating cost minus depreciation. Okay. We also have the taxes and we know the taxes amount equals to the uh earnings before income tax times the tax rate. We also have the net operating net operating profit after tax. So that is just the uh earnings before income tax minus the taxes and then operating cash flows of this value plus the depreciation. These are all different uh values that are considered when making a financial decision and each of them provides a great role in um helping us understand more of the um what kind of values and what kind of situations are happening behind the problem so that we are better informed before taking the decision to go ahead or um step back from setting up such a project. We also have the net uh present value calculations that we have to do and that is quite important because that's the main factor or concept used to determine if it's worth it or not to take the project and I can also combine the validate stage here because if you look at the equation um I can just show it soon. Yep. Net present value is the cash flow divided by 1 + D. R here would be the weighted average cost of capital. And if we go back to the code, it's using that same, you know, minus t minus the cash flow times / 1 + the rate raised to the um oh it's here raised to the um time the respective time. We can see right here sum of cash flow. So we know the code is using the exact same equation. So that's in a step of validating that the code is using the correct values and then we just know that the net present value is just going to discount all the cash flows from the different years as we know over the years the um value is going to be weaker. So we discount all of them to present worth just to have that stable value that we can use to evaluate whether the inflows are greater than outflows and so on. So if you look at oh yeah um the actual outflows or output here is a clear um cash flow timeline and we can see the total flow of cash flows. So year zero it was uh $12.5 million and it's here in thousands but the $500,000 from the working capital and then the 12 million from the investment. Then we have 8 million in revenue but we also have operating costs which we know uh vary over the years as well as claimed right here 40% of revenue labor utility rent marketing. So, yep, it's just a clear way of putting everything together and we have a clear uh statement of how much the cash flows are for each of the years. Now, here is the net net present value. So, all of these cash flows um just converted back to the I want to say the interest rate, but it's actually the weighted average cost of capital. So using that rate, we discount every single one of these cash flows to year zero. So we have that stable baseline to compare the values. So the net present value is actually 3,22,000 almost. We also have the internal rate of return and this is a way of calculating the this is a metric used to present how um metric used to present the cash flows and it's compared against the weighted average cost of capital to say whether to invest or not and we'll get into it a bit later. We also have the simple payback period which refers to how much time it takes for the cash outflows to equal the cash flow inflows. So it just looks at uh at what time does the sum of the cash flows in the future equal the $12.5 million investment. So it tells us 5.28. We have the discounted payback period. So that is how much time it takes for. So the simple payback period is just looking at the actual values whereas a discounted payback is referring to the um the discounted values which are adjusted according to the weighted average cost of capital or the rate. So this is more accurate than the simple payback period but it's just a different way to look at at what time the inflows equals outflows.

or the inflow inflows add up to outflows. And then we have the profitability profitability index of 1.24. I actually didn't show the equation for this, but it's right here. A roast acts as a halo project evaluating the entire Starbucks brand equity even if direct profits are marginal and it this project can also be an innovation hub as it provides a venue for testing premium products. And this is a warning sign as this value is lower than the weighted average cost of capital. So telling us if this was the case, we shouldn't be in investing in such a uh project. Now if the weighted average cost of capital increase by 2%. Our net present value also decreases because it's a higher rate. So the values are much weaker in the future. So if we can make that connection, but our irr is the same. So it's 13.25%. We have the if the rate average cost of capital decreases by 2%. The whack value is 6.5%. There's a critical risk in scenario 2 as a drop in 20% in revenue returns a negative net present value and this project has a high operating leverage and fixed cost consume profitability if volume drops. So that's just connecting back to the point on having high fixed costs which could eat into profitability if the revenue baseline is not uh consistent over time. And then we have discount rate sensitivity. So you know it just tells us how the vari cost of capital impacts the net present value. And we saw that right here. Um but the project remains value accurative even if the cost of capital rises to 10.5%. saying that even though there is quite a bit of change, the net present value is still pro uh positive, meaning that your inflows or revenue is actually greater than your investments or costs, which is a good thing. But companies will always look to maximize the net present value to ensure that their inflows or revenue is greater much greater than their costs. So overall I felt that this was quite a comprehensive and view on how to use financials and financial knowledge to make investment investment decisions as using factors or concepts such as time value of money. We have a better understanding of how we can use we can use the current time as a baseline and use uh discounted rates or discounted cash flows just to have that stable baseline to compare different years and different costs. And this allows us to make a more informed decision whether to take the investment or take the proposal or not. Thank you.

Marketing is 0.3 million in year 1 and 0.1 million thereafter. The taxes is 20% corporate rate. Terminal value is 3 million at end of year 10. Discount rate is 8.5% WACC. The objectives we have four of them. Um determine the instrumental cash flows. compute MPV, IR, payback periods and profitability index. We also want to see run sensitivity test for revenue drop and WCC changes and make a recommendation considering financial and strategic fit. So for our represent part um the c we have so first one we have cash flow timeline first one is year 10 we invest 12 million plus 0.5 million working capital for year 1 to 10 we have operating cash flows that's revenue minus operating cost minus taxes plus depreciation taxes shel and for year 10 we have recovered 0.5 million working capital plus 3 million terminal value for key mattress interests. So we have four of them. The first one is MPV, the present value of all cash flows minus initial investment. We have IRR, discount rate that makes MPV equals to zero. The payback period is the time to recover initial investment and then profitability index the present value of future cash flows divide the initial investment. We have uh risks and there's four of them. So revenue underperformance, higher financial costs and higher financing costs and the cost overruns in labor or marketing brand strategy misalignment. And then here we can click into our code. So if we see in here um there's the code that I have for this project and after we run it um we will have this Starbucks flexure royary analysis we have MPV we have IR and all the data then it has generate a graph for us for easier references and I copy it right here. So to validate our data for cash flows, we check the revenue minus cost, taxes and depreciation match, the annual cash flows and year 10 investment and year 10, oh sorry, year zero investment and year 10 terminal value plus the working capital should be correct. And for depreciation and taxes, so we have 1.2 million per year depreciation gives a 0.3 million tax shield. this applied properly in our in our section here and then we have metric so positive MPV of 3.0 3.02 million and IR of 13.25% above WACC of 8.5. So we can see here we have IRR of 13.25%. Uh we also have the MPV of about 3 million and the data is all here. That makes sense because the payback periods align with cash flow timing and the sensitivity. So the revenue drop and WC changes this affects the MPV and IR as expected when showing the model response logically. So for all the references we can check from the data that it generate for us. So all in all the model is consistent output are reasonable and it behaves correctly under different scenarios. So to involve the code that we have includes the revenue, cost and the ACC which makes testing different scenario straightforward and the graph that we have that also makes the result easier to understand and more clear to share with others. So these parts help show the numbers clearly making it easier for anyone reviewing the analyzis to see the risks and potential outcomes at a glance. The final reflex is that looking at our results, the project seems to create value seems to be good. The MPV is positive, the IR is above the hardo rate and the profitability index is over one. But the sensitivity tests show that if revenue drops a lot, um the MPV the MPV goes negative. So that's the biggest risk, the problem that we will have to look into. and changing the WACC didn't affect IR too much. So that was pretty interesting. And also if we go into the driver steps uh we can find that this helped things to get more organized. I feel that this process gives better understanding of both the financial modeling and how to think about the project risk. So all know um that's our final reflect for this project and thank you for watching.

Answer:
Hi everyone. My name is John Gasho, and this is my Section 6 Capital Budgeting analysis on Starbucks' proposed flagship roastery project. In this presentation I'm going to walk through the full DRIVER analytical process, demonstrate my Python model, and interpret the financial results — including NPV, IRR, payback periods, profitability index, and the key sensitivity analysis. This project applies Starbucks' 8.5% WACC as the hurdle rate to determine whether the investment creates value.

So now let me go to my code. These are just some endpoints I have. I begin with Define & Discover. I begin with Define & Discover, which is the most important stage and also the stage required for full credit. The goal here is not to build anything yet — it's to understand the decision, the financial structure of the project, and the information I need to model it.

The decision problem is: should Starbucks invest $12 million to build and operate a new flagship roastery that will run for 10 years? To answer that, I gathered all required inputs. The initial investment is $12 million, depreciated straight-line over 10 years. Working capital of $500,000 is invested at launch and fully recovered at the end of Year 10. Revenues are $8 million in Year 1, $11 million in Years 2–5, and $9 million in Years 6–10. Operating costs include cost of goods sold at 40% of revenue, labor at $2.5 million each year, rent and utilities at $0.8 million, and marketing at $0.3 million in Year 1 and $0.1 million in subsequent years. The tax rate is 25%. Terminal value is $3 million received in Year 10, and the discount rate is Starbucks' WACC of 8.5%. I also clarified the output requirements, which are to build a Year 0 through Year 10 incremental free cash-flow schedule. I also need to compute NPV and IRR, simple payback and discounted payback, and the profitability index, then run sensitivities for revenue down 20% and WACC ±2%, and provide an executive-ready recommendation that combines financial and strategic thinking.

Once all assumptions were defined, I was ready to move into the planning phase, which is the Represent stage. In the Represent stage I pre-designed the structure of the model before writing a single line of code. Represent is about designing the architecture. I broke my model into four components: the cash-flow engine, which computes revenues, operating costs, EBIT, taxes, depreciation (and the tax shield), working capital movements, terminal value, and free cash flow from Years 0 to 10; the value-metrics engine, which calculates NPV at 8.5%, IRR, simple payback, discounted payback, and profitability index; the scenario and sensitivity module, which runs the model for revenue at −20%, WACC at 6.5%, and WACC at 10.5%; and visual outputs, including bar charts showing free cash flows across all 11 years and additional visuals for scenario comparison. I also planned the DRIVER printouts that document each stage as I worked. Once the structure was represented, I moved into the Implementation stage.

In Implementation I wrote the Python code exactly according to the plan while keeping everything parameterized so any assumptions can be easily adjusted. My assumption section defines all project parameters — revenues, costs, depreciation, and WACC — at the top. This ensures a transparent model that anyone can update without touching the logic. I implemented the build_cashflows() function. This function calculates COGS at 40% of revenue, adds labor, rent, and marketing, subtracts operating costs, computes annual depreciation, calculates EBIT and taxes, adds back depreciation, adjusts for working capital, and adds terminal value in Year 10. This satisfies the assignment requirement to model incremental free cash flows from Year 0 through Year 10. The financial_metrics() function computes NPV using Starbucks' 8.5% WACC, IRR, profitability index, simple payback, and discounted payback, which satisfies the requirement to produce all core capital-budgeting metrics. I built a small scenario engine that returns the model under revenue −20%, WACC = 6.5%, and WACC = 10.5%, and I plotted yearly free cash flow so the investment profile is clear. Finally, I included clean, sequential DRIVER messages so my work is fully documented, meeting the assignment's critical requirement to show the analytical progression rather than reverse-engineer a completed model. Then I ran the model and here are the results.

In the Validate stage I checked the mechanics to ensure the model was operating correctly. I verified that depreciation equals $12 million divided by 10 years, which is $1.2 million per year. Working capital is subtracted in Year 0 and fully recovered in Year 10. Terminal value is added only in Year 10. Revenue and operating-cost logic match all problem parameters. Free cash flows show the correct pattern — a large outflow in Year 0, stable operating inflows during Years 1–9, and a large inflow in Year 10 from terminal value plus the working-capital recovery. After checking EBIT, taxes, NOPAT, and cash flows, everything validated properly. Then I proceeded to sensitivity analysis.

In the Evolve stage I focused on scalability. Because my model is fully parameterized, I can change any assumptions — revenue growth, WACC, rents, marketing — and the model updates instantly. For future expansion, I identified enhancements such as adding a cannibalization adjustment, running Monte Carlo simulations, modeling monthly construction cash flows, and considering multi-stage capex. These improvements would enhance decision confidence in a corporate setting.

In the Reflect stage — the final stage — I combine interpretation with strategic judgment. Base-case results at 8.5% WACC are: NPV = $3,022,515, IRR = 13.25%, discounted payback ≈ 8.2 years, simple payback ≈ 5.3 years, and profitability index ≈ 1.24. The project passes the financial tests. A positive NPV means the roastery creates value. The IRR exceeds the WACC by almost five percentage points. PI above 1 confirms benefits outweigh costs. Payback is long, but that is normal for strategic flagship locations. The cash-flow visualization clearly shows a typical retail investment profile: a large upfront cost in Year 0, stable operating inflows throughout the asset's life, and a final spike in Year 10 reflecting depreciation tax shield, working-capital recovery, and terminal value. I was satisfied with these results. I used ChatGPT to help refine wording, but I primarily supplied the inputs and model logic.

Sensitivity analysis shows that revenue −20% yields NPV ≈ −$2.75 million, which is the most important insight: the roastery is extremely sensitive to revenue performance. A 20% drop wipes out all value, meaning consumer traffic, pricing power, and marketing execution must be closely managed. Sensitivity to WACC ±2% shows that at WACC = 6.5%, NPV ≈ $4.64 million, and at WACC = 10.5%, NPV ≈ $1.63 million. Even at a higher cost of capital the project remains financially viable, demonstrating resilience to capital-market conditions. The main risk is not financing — it is revenue.

Based on my analysis, I recommend accepting the Starbucks roastery investment. The financial case is compelling: a positive base-case NPV, an IRR that exceeds the WACC, a strong profitability index, and robust results under higher discount rates. Beyond the numbers, the project supports Starbucks' strategic brand goals. It strengthens premium and experiential brand positioning, creates a tourist attraction and a high-visibility flagship site, and supports long-term brand equity and global differentiation. However, Starbucks must proactively manage demand uncertainty, as the revenue-downside scenario shows that underperformance in traffic or pricing materially damages value. Marketing, consumer engagement, and site selection are key risk areas. Overall, the roastery creates financial value, supports strategic objectives, and is worth pursuing — with attention to demand risk.

That completes my DRIVER-based capital-budgeting analysis. Thank you for listening.
