Answer:
Hi, my name is Hillary Tobias, and this is my video for the Session 10 Assignment. I'll start with the Define and Discover stage of the DRIVER framework. My objective for this assignment is to use core capital budgeting metrics to provide an accept or reject decision for Starbucks' proposed flagship roastery. The scope and horizon for this scenario is that Starbucks' roastery is expected to operate for 10 years. The constraints for this assignment are that I am limited to the data that was provided, but I don't think that should be an issue. My success metric for this assignment will be successfully calculating the core capital budgeting metrics and then using those to provide a recommendation. And some of the capital budgeting metrics I will calculate include net present value, internal rate of return, and profitability index, along with some other ones. The benchmark for this assignment will be using the base case scenario to compare different sensitivity analysis scenarios to.

Continuing with the Define and Discover stage of the DRIVER framework, I'll now go over the data inventory that was provided for this assignment. I was told that the initial investment will be $12 million, and that will include the building, equipment, and training, and this investment will be depreciated using the straight-line method over 10 years. Starbucks' weighted average cost of capital is 8.5%. I was told that this project will require a half a million dollars of working capital to be deployed at the launch of the project, and that amount will be recovered in year 10. As far as revenues go for this project, it is projected that it will bring in $8 million of revenue in year 1, $11 million in years 2 through 5, and $9 million of revenue in years 6 through 10. Continuing with the data inventory, as far as operating costs go, I was told that cost of goods sold will be 40% of revenue, labor will cost $2.5 million each year, rent and utilities will be $0.8 million each year, and marketing will be $0.3 million in year 1 and then $0.1 million the remaining nine years. Starbucks' corporate tax rate is 25%, and I was told that the terminal value at year 10 will be $3 million.

Now I'll move on to the Represent stage of the DRIVER framework. And in this stage, I came up with four steps to help me complete this analysis. Step one will be to visualize the cash flows for years 0 through 10, and I will do this using my Python code. In those cash flows, I will include revenue, operating costs, depreciation tax shields, taxes, working capital changes, and terminal value. Step two will be to calculate the core capital budgeting metrics, and I will also use Python to do this. The metrics that I will calculate are net present value, internal rate of return, simple payback period, discounted payback period, and profitability index. I also plan to parameterize my assumptions so that revenue, cost, and discount rate inputs can be updated easily.

Step three will be to perform sensitivity analysis, also using my Python code. The sensitivity scenarios that I will test will be if revenue is reduced by 20%, and then if the weighted average cost of capital is increased or decreased by 2%. I will then summarize the impact of these changes on the capital budgeting metrics, and I will also show a graph of how sensitive net present value is to changes in weighted average cost of capital. Finally, step four of my plan will be to provide the accept or reject decision. I will provide this decision by using the financial metrics that I calculated and also considering the strategic fit, brand implications, and risks of this project. 

Now I'll move on to the Implement stage of the DRIVER framework. In order to implement my plan, I provided Google Gemini with my objective for the assignment, all of the data that was provided in the data inventory, and also the first three steps of my plan from the Represent stage because those are the three steps that I wanted to use Python code for. I asked Google Gemini for any suggestions to my plan, and it gave me some refined logic. And then after that, I asked Gemini to write simple Python code that would execute my plan. Now I'll switch over to Google Colab to show you the code that I ended up with. The first thing the code does is import the necessary libraries it needs for this analysis. And then it sets up the parameters and assumptions for this case. So it starts with the weighted average cost of capital, which was 8.5%, the tax rate, which is 25%, the number of years for the project, which is 10, the initial investment, which was $12 million, the initial outlay of working capital, which was $500,000, and the gross terminal value, which was $3 million. The next thing the code does is define the core function that it will use to run this analysis, and that function is called, "Evaluate Project." The first thing that the code does is build the timeline, so it builds a range of the number of years of the project.

The next thing the code does is construct the revenue schedule. For the initial scenario, that would be $0 of revenue in year 0, and then $8 million of revenue in year 1, $11 million of revenue in the next four years, and then $9 million of revenue in the last five years. Next, the code sets up the operating expenses. It starts with cost of goods sold, which is 40% of revenue. So, in order to find the amount for cost of goods sold, it takes the amount of revenue and multiplies it by 0.4. Then, it sets up the amount for labor, which was $2.5 million each year. Next, it does rent and utilities, which was $800,000 each year. And finally, it sets up the marketing costs, which will be $0 in year 0, $300,000 in year 1, and then $100,000 in the remaining 9 years. The next section of code is where it calculates the amount of annual depreciation. It finds this by taking the initial investment of $12 million and dividing that by the total years for the project, which was 10. So that will result in annual depreciation of $1.2 million.

Next, the code moves on to calculating earnings before interest and taxes, and then also net operating profit after taxes. The first number that it finds is the total for the operating expenses, and in order to find that, it adds the cost of goods sold, the labor cost, rent and utilities, marketing, and the depreciation expense. And next, it finds earnings before interest and taxes, which is also known as operating profit. And it finds that by taking revenue and then subtracting the total operating expenses. The next number that it calculates is the amount of taxes for each year, and it finds that by multiplying the operating profit by the tax rate. And then the last number that it calculates in this section is the net operating profit after taxes, and in order to find that, it takes the operating profit and subtracts the tax amount. The next thing the code does is build the free cash flows, and the first thing it does in this section is add back depreciation. Depreciation was deducted from earnings when calculating the tax amount because depreciation is a tax-deductible expense and therefore it reduces the amount of tax a company has to pay. And this concept is known as the depreciation tax shield. But since depreciation was deducted from earnings, we then have to add it back when considering the cash flows because it's a non-cash expense. So, after adding back depreciation, then the code sets up the capital expenditure, which will be the initial $12 million investment in year 0. The next thing the code sets up is the changes in working capital. So, in year 0, that will be a negative cash outflow of $500,000. And then in year 10, it will recover that working capital, so that will be a positive cash flow of $500,000. And then the next thing the code handles is the terminal value. And so, I was given the gross amount of the terminal value, but that will be taxable. So in order to find the amount of tax on that gain, the code multiplies the gross amount of the terminal value by the tax rate. And then in order to find the net terminal value, it takes the gross terminal value and subtracts the amount of tax. And then that gives it the net terminal value.

And then the next thing the code does is calculate the total free cash flow for each year. And so in order to do this, it takes the net operating profit after taxes, adds the depreciation add back, adds any capital expenditures, which will be the initial $12 million cash outlay in year 0, adds any changes in working capital, which will be in year 0 and year 10, and adds the net terminal value of the investment, which will occur in year 10. 

Next, the code moves on to calculating the capital budgeting metrics. The first one it calculates is net present value. So that finds the present value of all of the cash flows related to this investment and it uses the weighted average cost of capital as the discount rate. And the next number the code finds is the internal rate of return. And then after that, the code moves on to calculating the simple payback period. And so it finds the payback period by finding the cumulative cash flows. And then it finds the last year that the cash flows are negative, and then it finds the fraction of the next year that it takes to recover the initial cost of the investment. And so then it takes whatever number the last negative year was and adds the fraction of the next year to find the total for the payback period. And then the next thing the code calculates is the discounted payback period. In order to find this, it finds the present value of each specific year's cash flow using the weighted average cost of capital as the discount rate. And then it uses the same logic that it used for the simple payback period of finding cumulative cash flows, and then finding the last negative year and adding the fraction of the next year it takes to recover the investment.

Next, the code moves on to calculating profitability index. So, it identifies what the total initial cash outflow of this project was, which would be the $12 million capital expenditure plus the $500,000 of working capital that would be needed in year zero. And then it calculates the present value of cash flows from year 1 onwards. And then it calculates the profitability index by taking the present value of the future cash flows and dividing that by the initial cash outlay.

The next section of code just tells you what the output will display. So it will tell you which scenario it is running the function for and then it will tell you the NPV, IRR, simple payback, discounted payback, profitability index, and all of those metrics that it calculated.

So the next section of code is where it gets into calling that function. It starts by calling the function for the base case scenario and all of the original facts that we were given. And then it formats that scenario and prints out the calculation of the cash flows for each year. And then it also prints out all of the metrics that were calculated for that scenario. And it also will provide an accept or reject decision. And this code's decision is based simply on if NPV is positive or negative, which I will also use whenever I give my recommendation, but I will use the other metrics as well.

Next, the code moves on to performing the sensitivity analysis. In order to do this, it runs the "Evaluate Project" function for four different scenarios. It starts with the base case scenario to use as a benchmark. Then it runs the function as if revenue decreased by 20%. Next, it runs it as if the weighted average cost of capital was 10.5%. And finally, it runs that function as if the weighted average cost of capital was 6.5%. And then it has code that will display the results from that sensitivity analysis.

And then the next section of code sets up the two visualizations that it will provide. The first graph that it will show will be a waterfall chart of the yearly cash flows, so you can see if they're negative or positive. And the second visualization that it will show is the sensitivity of the net present value to changes in the weighted average cost of capital. So now I'll run this code so you can see how it works.

The first thing in the output is the display of the yearly cash flows. So you can see it has years 0 through 10 here and it shows the amount of revenue, operating income, taxes, net operating profit after taxes, and free cash flow for each year. And then below that, it shows all of the metrics it calculated. It found the net present value to be about $2.7 million. The internal rate of return is 12.84%. The simple payback period is 5.28 years. The discounted payback period is 8.21 years. The profitability index is 1.22, and based on the positive net present value, it recommends accepting this project.

The next section of output shows the results of the sensitivity analysis. This first line shows the base case scenario, and it shows the net present value of the base case scenario, the internal rate of return, the simple payback period, discounted payback period, and profitability index. And then it also shows all of those metrics for the decrease in revenue and the increase and decrease in cost of capital. And as you can see, whenever revenue is decreased by 20%, then the net present value became negative $3 million. The internal rate of return became 3.13%. Simple payback period became 9.3 years. It actually would not recover its initial investment based on the discounted payback period, and the profitability index was only 0.75. And then for the two different costs of capital, the net present value was still positive. The internal rate of return was the same. The simple payback period was the same. The discounted payback period was slightly different, and the profitability index was still above one for both of those.

Next is the visualization of the free cash flows for the base case scenario. And it shows the large initial cash out outflow in year 0 of $12.5 million. And then after that you can see the various positive cash flows in years 1 through 10, and they vary based on the amount of revenue for each year. And then also year 10 is greater because that includes the recovery of the working capital and the terminal value. And lastly is the graph of the sensitivity of the net present value to changes in cost of capital. The cost of capital is used as the discount rate in the calculation of net present value. And the cost of capital is on the x-axis here and net present value in millions of dollars is on the y-axis, and this blue line shows the relationship between the two. So, as you can see, whenever the cost of capital is lower, net present value is higher. And then as cost of capital increases, net present value decreases. And this red line shows the break-even point where net present value equals zero. And this green line here shows the internal rate of return, which was 12.8%. And as you can see, whenever the weighted average cost of capital is equal to the internal rate of return at 12.8%, that is where net present value equals zero. 

Now I will go back to my slides and move on to the Validation stage of the DRIVER framework. In order to validate the results from my code, I created an Excel worksheet to check all of the calculations. So, I mapped out all the cash flows and then I used Excel's net present value and internal rate of return functions to find those numbers. I performed this verification for the base case scenario and all of the sensitivity analysis scenarios. Whenever I was checking all the numbers, I found that the code was calculating the profitability index incorrectly, so I corrected that. And then I also found that the code did not initially include a calculation of the discounted payback period. It was only doing the simple payback period, so I added in the calculation of discounted payback period. And other than that, all of my numbers were correct, so that was good. And I will show you my worksheet here. So, you can see here are all the cash flows for the base case scenario, and over here are where I calculated the capital budgeting metrics. And all these numbers are the same that my code gave me. And then here are the cash flows and the metrics for the decreased revenue scenario. Here are the numbers for the increased cost of capital scenario. And finally, here are the numbers for the decreased cost of capital scenario.

Now, I'll move on to the Evolve stage of the DRIVER framework, and in this stage, I will discuss the sensitivity analysis a little bit further. The sensitivity analysis from this case showed us how different assumptions might change the ultimate investment decision, and it also highlights how important it is to have good estimates. As we saw in this case, if revenue falls short of the original estimates by 20%, the project will have a negative net present value, which means it will destroy value to the firm rather than create value for the firm. So, in that case, you would not want to accept this project. And we also saw that the weighted average cost of capital changes still both resulted in positive net present values, and internal rate of returns that were greater than both of the cost of capitals, and also profitability indexes that were greater than one. So, in both of those cases, we would still accept this project. And sensitivity analysis is important to any capital budgeting decision, and it can be really useful for analyzing different cases such as a best-case and worst-case scenario and determining if you should accept or reject a large investment project.

Now I'll move on to the Reflect stage of the DRIVER framework, and in this stage, I will revisit all of the capital budgeting metrics that I calculated, and I will also discuss some other strategic implications of this investment, and finally, I will provide my ultimate recommendation to either accept or reject this project. Starting with net present value, that is the total value a project will add to a company in today's dollars. A positive net present value creates value for the firm, but a negative net present value destroys value for the firm. And the NPV rule is that you should accept the project if net present value is greater than zero, and you should reject the project if net present value is less than zero. In our case, the net present value was about $2.7 million, which was positive, so based on that, I would recommend accepting this project. The next metric I found was internal rate of return, and that is the expected annual percentage return of the project, and it is also the discount rate that would force the net present value to equal zero. The internal rate of return rule is that you should accept the project if IRR is greater than the cost of capital, but you should reject the project if IRR is less than the cost of capital. In our case, the internal rate of return was 12.84%, which was greater than the cost of capital which was 8.5%. So based on the internal rate of return, I would also recommend accepting this project.

The next metric that I calculated was payback period, which measures the time it takes for an investment to generate enough cash flow to recover its initial investment. Shorter payback periods are preferred because they suggest lower risk and greater potential returns, whereas longer payback periods indicate higher risks associated with the project. The payback period rule is that you should accept the project if the payback period is shorter than the company's specific cut-off target. For this assignment, I was not given a specific cut-off target for Starbucks, but I found that their simple payback period was 5.28 years and their discounted payback period was 8.21 years. So, if these amounts of time are shorter than the company's cut-off target, then it should accept this project.

The next metric I calculated was profitability index, which compares the value a project is expected to create to the cost of the project. If a profitability index is greater than one, it indicates that a project is expected to generate more value than its cost, but if a profitability index is less than one, that indicates that the project is not expected to cover its initial investment. So, the profitability index rule is that you should accept the project if the index is greater than one, but you should reject the project if the index is less than one. In our case the profitability index was 1.22, which is greater than one, so I would recommend accepting the project based on that. Another important note on profitability index is that it is very useful for ranking projects. So if the company has several capital budgeting decisions that it's trying to make and it can only invest in one, then it should invest in the one with the highest profitability index because that is the one that will create the most value relative to its cost.

Next, I'll go over the sensitivity analysis again. Once again, we saw that the project should be rejected if the revenues are 20% lower than the original estimates because this resulted in a negative net present value, an internal rate of return lower than the cost of capital, it would not recover its investment using the discounted payback period method, and its profitability index was less than one. I would still accept the project even if the cost of capital was 2% higher or lower because all of these metrics were still good and pass the test to accept the project.

Also, for the sensitivity analysis, based on the graph that was generated by the code, we can see that if the cost of capital were to increase beyond the internal rate of return of 12.84%, that is when net present value would become negative, and then is when you would reject the project. So as long as the cost of capital is less than 12.84%, then it would be good to accept this project.

Now I'll move on to some strategic implications of this investment. As far as a strategic fit goes, this flagship roastery is a very specific, premium type of retail location. And it's not only a retail location, but it's also branded as an experience of seeing the whole manufacturing process of the coffee. And these roasteries are designed to elevate the brand image and make the brand appear as more of a "premium" company. These roasteries are typically very large establishments in premium locations, and these roasteries also charge significantly higher prices than standard Starbucks stores. And customers spend more per visit when they visit these flagship roasteries compared to a standard Starbucks.

Some implications of this investment for the overall brand of Starbucks are that it would elevate overall brand equity. It would also enable Starbucks to charge more in its other stores since the brand is seen as being a "premium" company. And this roastery could also be used as a testing ground for new products before Starbucks rolls those products out worldwide, which could be very beneficial for the company. And lastly, this investment also creates a competitive advantage for Starbucks because it differentiates it from its competitors who don't have these premium stores. Some key risks related to this investment are, first of all, the very large capital expenditure. We saw that it would require a $12.5 million initial cash outlay from the beginning, and then in addition to that capital expenditure, these roasteries also tend to have very high operating expenses due to the large staff that is needed, the specialized master roasters that are needed, and the expenses of operating in a prime location. And another risk is that this premium roastery may compete with the standard Starbucks that are nearby, and the premium roastery might just eat into the profits of the other surrounding Starbucks, which would not be good.

So, my final decision recommendation is to accept this investment project. I recommend accepting the project because all of the core capital budgeting metrics for the base case scenario resulted in an acceptance decision. However, it is important to point out that the company should be mindful of its estimates, and it should be very confident in its projections of revenue, because the sensitivity analysis showed that whenever revenue fell by 20% then the project turned into destroying value for the firm, and in that case, it should reject this project. So based on that, I would recommend that Starbucks make sure they are very confident that they will achieve at least the amount of revenue that was given in the base case scenario. And not only do I recommend investing in this roastery because of the financial metrics, but I also think it will be a good strategic move for Starbucks. The roastery will improve the overall brand equity of Starbucks, which will help the company become known as a premium producer of coffee products and it will separate it from its competitors. Thanks!

Answer: Hi, this is Andrea and in session 10, I'm pulling together everything from time value of money and cost of capital to make a big capital budgeting decision using NVP. First, using a driver method, I'm going to define and discover. So, imagine I'm on Apple's capital location committee, a location committee. Tim Cook asks, should we spend $2 billion to build an advanced semiconductor factory in Texas? So the finance team gives this cash flow forecast from years one to three $500 million per year which would be the ramp up uh period from years 4 to 8 and 800 million per year which would be a full reproduction from years 9 to 10 $300 million per year which declines the purchase and in year 10 plus 200 million from selling the facility. Apple's WACC is 8.5%. So that's our hurdle rate. The strate The strategy team is excited about supply chain independence and ops says outsourcing might be cheaper. So my job is to cut through emotions and ask one clear question. Does this project create shareholder value in finance language? is MVP greater than zero when we discount all cash flows at Apple's WACC of 8 point 8.5%. So the goal in this session is to use capital budgeting as a glue that connects time value of money risk and return and WACC to make a clean accept or reject decision with the second step of the driver method we represent. So, first I map the cash flow timeline. I'll measure everything in millions. Year zero, meaning today, would be CF0 equaling minus $2,000. This is the 2 billion investment. So, in years 1 2 3, CF1 it would be 500. CF2 500, CF3 500. And from years 4 to 8, CF4 to CF8 would be 800. And then in years 9 to 10, CF9 would be 300. CF10 would be 300 plus 200. That's the 200 is the sale value, which would equal 500. So the cash flow stream is um - 2,500 500 500 800 800 800 800 800 300 and 500. And the NVP formula is NVP equals the sum of T = 0 um to 10 of C of F of T divided by 1 + R to the T where CF0 would be the minus 20,000 we talked about and C FT are the future cash flows. R would be 8.5% which is Apple's WACC. So the decision rule is that if NPV is greater than zero then the project creates value so we accept it. If NVP is um lower than zero it destroys value so we reject it. Now um to implement I'm going to use a simple Python MVP example you can see on screen. So now I turn that timeline into a very simple Python script. I'm not trying to be uh I'm just doing a simple Python script. So just I so that I can just translate a story uh into a code. So when I run this the MVP comes out strongly positive around 2.1 billion in today's dollars which means that after covering up 8.5% cost of capital there is still a lot of value left over for shareholders. Here you can see the MVP and then you can it also does the accept or reject decision. In this case, we obviously accept the project because the MVP is positive. Now for our driver method, we verify. And to verify my analysis makes sense, I check three things. First, cash flows. And I ask myself, did I include the initial investment, operating cash flows, and the terminal value? Um, yes, I did as you can see. Then second, the discount rate. I used Apple's WACCC of 8.5% which is the right hurdle rate for a project with similar risk to Apple's core business. And third, the decision rule NPV is well above zero. So the project clearly creates shareholder value that matches the intuition that a two billion spend that generates large cash flows for 10 years plus a sale at the end should be attractive if the numbers are realistic. So the math and the business story are perfectly aligned. Then um for the next step on the driver meth method we evolve. So I evolved the analysis but I but I asking some what if questions. I asked myself what if the project is riskier than Apple's core business to this I I thought then the discount rate should be higher than 8.5% and I can change the WACC in the code to 10% or 12% and see how MVP changes. The other question I did to myself is what if the cash flows are over optimistic? I can multiply each feature future cash flow by let's say about a 0.8 uh which would be a 20% haircut and return the model to see whether NVP is still positive. This is how co cor cooperative finance terms use sensitivity analysis and scenarios to see whether a project is still attractive when key assumptions move against them. for the last um uh step on the driver method. My biggest I reflect. So my biggest insight from session 10 is that capital budgeting is where everything comes together. Where TVM gives me the mechanics to discount future cash flows where WACC gives me the market based discount rate that reflects risk. Cash flow analysis forces me to think carefully about what actually changes if we do the project and MVP turns a messy emotional strategic idea into a single objective number. Does this investment create value after paying investors the great return? So in Apple's example, instead of arguing we need supply chain independence versus outsourcing is cheaper, MVP let's give gives us the opportunity to say at an 8.5% cost of capital the factory adds billions in present value. So financially it's a go unless there are huge qualitative risks we haven't priced in. The same logic is exactly what I'll apply in my Starbucks sorcery assignment. Well, I will build incremental cash flows, discount them at WACC, compute N and PV and IRR, test sensitives, and then make a clear manager friendly recommendation that connects the number two strategy. That's what I learned on session 10 that using NVPN capital budgeting as a disciplined way for companies to decide which big projects deserve their their scarce capital. Thank you so much. That was my session 10 assignment.

Hi, my name is Daniel Verachtert and this is my session 10 cost of capital analysis.

Uh so to start, what problem are we solving? Should Starbucks invest 12 million in a 10-year flagship roaster? Um the objective is maximize shareholder value using capital budgeting. The hurdle rate uh which is the whack is 8.5%. Does the roaster create value after covering Starbucks 8.5 cost 8.5% cost of capital that's like what we're trying to find. And then um initial cost is 12 million plus the 500k in working capital. So key project uh project inputs and assumptions. So the revenues in year one it's 8 million. Year two through five it's 11 million. Year 6 through 10 it's 9 million. The operating cost, the cost of goods sold is 40% of revenue. The labor is 2.5 million. Rent and utilities is 800,000. Marketing is 300,000 in year one and then 100,000 every year after. Um depreciation is 12 million and over the 10 years that makes it 1.2 million per year. It's straight line depreciation. The tax rate is 25% working capital is 500k for year zero and then it's returned uh on in year 10 and then terminal value is 3 million in year 10. So to start these are the revenue projections I have. So what we can learn from this graph that I have is uh well one revenue drives almost every part of the uh free cash flow model. So because it has an effect on the cost of goods sold EBIT taxes and operating cash flow. It's the primary value driver. Two, the roaster behaves like a flagship retail plus tourism asset. You could see that because in year one there's a large jump because of the high like touristy like hype and then it peaks around two to five years and like stays there and then uh finally in the long term it uh normalizes at 0.9. Um finally or sorry uh the revenue curve explains why sensitivity analysis matters. Since revenue rises in the dips, one the project generates large cash flows early on and two uh long-term value depends heavily on sustaining year two through five performance. Uh when revenue is cut 20% across all years, it destroys the uh NPV.

So operating cost and depreciation. Uh so some of the values that we need to know here the cost of goods sold is 0.4 4 times the revenue for the year. Down here we can see um so year one 8 million in revenue that times point4 would be 3.2 million and then you could see the same for the rest of the years. Uh the depreciation is 12 million and that over the 10 years is 1.2 million per year. So right here depreciation 1.2 2 million per year. Uh depreciation tax shield is uh depreciation times the tax rate. So it's 300,000 in tax savings each year. Um EBIT EBIT's the revenue minus cost of goods sold minus labor minus rent minus marketing minus depreciation. So in year 1 it's zero. Year two through five it's 2 million. And then 6 through 10 it's 800,000. um these. So that that's more on the depreciation factors. And then as for operating costs, we can see the variable cost is just cost of goods sold, which is 40% of the revenue per year right here. And then the fixed costs are labor, which is 2.5 million each year, rent and utilities, which is 800,000 per year, and marketing, which in year 1 is 300,000, and then 100,000 year two through uh 10. Uh my free cash flow model. So taxes equals EBIT*.25 operating cash flow equals EBIT * 1 - 0.25 plus depreciation. working capital adjustments. So year one it's minus 500,000, year 10 it's plus 500,000 and then the final free cash flow is um operating cash flow plus the change in working uh cash flow and uh then plus the terminal misspelled terminal. Uh we can look at this graph and see that the first year there's a big decrease. It's a It's $12 million down and then you could see as it grows and then goes down and then grows again because of the return of the working capital adjustment. Uh here's like the numbers per year. So you could see that uh the revenue for each year is here. The operating costs and then depreciation EBIT taxes, operating cash flow, working cash uh or change capex and then the terminal value and then the free cash flow which is the big thing. So you can see the free cash flow increases each year and it's always positive which is what you want to see comes out to 5,300,000 at the end. Answer:
1. D - Define & Discover
This stage focuses on clearly understanding the capital budgeting decision, validating the project parameters, and defining the strategic scope of the investment analysis.
Problem: Starbucks is evaluating a strategic "Flagship Roastery" project requiring a substantial $12 million upfront capital outlay and a $500,000 working capital injection. To assess the economic viability of this 10-year project, we must determine if the generated Free Cash Flows (FCF) provide a return exceeding the firm's Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC) of 8.5%. The analysis must determine if the project creates shareholder value (positive NPV) or if the funds should be deployed elsewhere.
Goal: The objective is to build a transparent, dynamic Python-based cash-flow model to calculate NPV, IRR, and Payback Period, providing a data-backed "Accept" or "Reject" recommendation that accounts for both financial metrics and sensitivity to revenue volatility.
Fact Verification - Important First Step: A common analytical error in capital budgeting is mismanaging the timing of cash flows, particularly Working Capital and Terminal Value. We must explicitly verify that the $500,000 Working Capital is an outflow at Year 0 and a recapture (inflow) at Year 10. Additionally, we must confirm that the $3 million Terminal Value is treated as a taxable cash inflow at the end of the project life, distinct from the depreciation schedule.
Hypothesis: Given the high initial investment ($12M) relative to the Year 1 revenue ($8M), the project will likely have a long payback period. However, the surge in revenue during Years 2-5 ($11M) should drive the NPV positive, provided that operating costs (specifically the fixed labor and rent) do not erode the margin too heavily. The project will likely be highly sensitive to revenue fluctuations due to the high fixed cost structure (high operating leverage).
Action: Confirm the tax treatment of the asset. Since the $12M is depreciated straight-line over 10 years, the Book Value at Year 10 will be $0. Consequently, the entire $3M Terminal Value will be treated as a taxable gain (Recapture).
Communication Plan: If the Net Present Value (NPV) is marginally positive but the Internal Rate of Return (IRR) is close to the WACC (8.5%), the recommendation must rely heavily on the strategic "Flagship" branding benefits rather than pure financial arbitrage.
Key Questions to Answer:
Does the project generate a positive Net Present Value (NPV) using the 8.5% hurdle rate?
How long does it take to recover the initial $12.5M cash outlay (Discounted Payback Period)?
How does the reduction of revenue in Years 6-10 impact the total value creation?
If revenue misses projections by 20%, does the project destroy value (turn NPV negative)?
Is the project robust enough to survive a 2% increase in the cost of capital (WACC)?
 
2. R - Represent (The Plan) 
This stage outlines the analytical and technical steps required to construct the cash flow model and compute the core capital budgeting metrics.
Core Formula & Methodology
The analysis will be centered on calculating the Incremental Free Cash Flow (FCF) for each year and discounting it back to the present value to find the Net Present Value (NPV).
Annual Straight-Line Depreciation:
 Depreciation = Initial Investment / Project life
Operating Cash Flow (OCF):
 OCF = (Revenues − COGS − Operating Costs − Depreciation) × (1 − t) + Depreciation
Free Cash Flow (FCF):
 Free Cash Flow = Operating Cash Flow − Capital Expenditure − ΔNet WorkingCapital + Terminal Cash Flow
Net Present Value (NPV):
 Net Present Value = t=1 ∑ N​ (1 + Weighted AVerage Cost of Capital) Free Cash Flow at Time − Initial Outlay
N = Number of Periods (N=10)
Analytical Process (Steps)
The process will be conducted in a sequential, calculated manner, leveraging a Python function to parameterize the assumptions:
Step 1: Model Setup and Constant Calculation (Depreciation)
Define all project parameters (Investment, Weighted Average Cost of Capital, Tax Rate, Revenues, Costs) as variables in Python.
Calculate the constant annual depreciation.
Step 2: Incremental Cash Flow Schedule Construction
Create a loop for Years 1 through 10.
Inside the loop, dynamically calculate: Revenues, COGS, Total Operating Costs (excluding depreciation), Depreciation, Taxable Income (EBIT), Taxes, and Free Cash Flow.
Special Cash Flows:
Year 0: Calculate total initial outlay = −Investment−Net Working Capital.
Year 10: Add the Non-Operating Terminal Cash Flows: Recovery of Net Working Capital and Terminal Value (after tax on the salvage gain). Since the Book Value is $0, the entire $3M is a taxable gain.
Step 3: Core Metric Calculation (Base Case)
Use the Free Cash Flow array and the Base Weighted Average Cost of Capital (8.5%) to compute the NPV, IRR, Discounted Payback, and Profitability Index (PI).
Step 4: Sensitivity Analysis Implementation
Create parameterized functions to re-run Step 2 and 3 for the two required scenarios:
Scenario A: Revenue multiplier set to 0.8 (20% reduction).
Scenario B: WACC set to 6.5% and 10.5%.
Summarize the impact on NPV and IRR.

3. I - Implement (The Analysis & Code) 
The model was implemented using Python's numpy-financial (Python Library (Numeric Python - Financial)) library to execute the cash flow projections and metric calculations. The base case uses the Weighted Average Cost of Capital of 8.5% and 100% of the projected revenues.

Conclusion: All three primary value metrics (NPV, IRR, PI) indicate that the roastery project should be accepted, as it is projected to create over $3.0 million in value for Starbucks.

4. V - Validate (Accuracy and Sense Check) 
This stage verifies the computed results against established financial rules and tests the robustness of the valuation using the implemented scenarios.
Sensitivity Analysis Summary
The model was subjected to the two required sensitivity tests.
Scenario
WACC Rev Multiplier NPV Impact ($M) IRR Impact (%) Recommendation Base Case

Interpretation of Risk
Revenue Volatility (CRITICAL RISK): The project is highly vulnerable to underperforming sales due to high operating leverage (high fixed costs relative to revenue). A 20% reduction in revenue (Scenario A) causes the NPV to become significantly negative (-$2.75 Million) and the IRR (3.88%) to fall far below the 8.5% hurdle rate. This finding suggests the revenue forecast is the single greatest financial risk to project viability.
WACC Robustness (LOW RISK): The project's value is robust to changes in the cost of capital. Even if the WACC increases by 200bps to 10.5%, the NPV remains positive at $1.63 million.

5. E - Evolve (Critique and Next Steps) 
This stage critiques the static assumptions used in the implemented model and suggests technical and analytical improvements for a more refined analysis.
Technical Critique: Payback Period Error
A critical error was found in the model's computation of the Payback Periods. The cash flow schedule shows an initial outlay of -$12.5 Million and a Year 1 cash flow of +$1.2 Million. A payback period of 0.52 years is mathematically incorrect. The actual simple payback period should be closer to 5.2 years. This indicates a likely logic error in how the cumulative cash flow was tracked in the underlying code, and the metric should be disregarded for the final recommendation.
Analytical Critique of Assumptions
Terminal Value Tax Treatment: The model correctly assumes the entire $3M Terminal Value is a taxable gain because the Book Value = 0. However, in a real scenario, the Terminal Value should reflect the after-tax sale of the asset and the present value of continued operations (a perpetuity), which would likely add more value than a fixed $3M sale price.
Depreciation Method: The model uses straight-line depreciation. The Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System is typically used for tax purposes, which accelerates depreciation and creates a larger tax shield in the early years. This would increase the early-year Free Cash Flow, resulting in a higher NPV and a faster discounted payback.
Next Steps for Deeper Analysis
The immediate next step is to rigorously stress-test the project's viability around the critical risk identified: revenue shortfall. Management should determine the break-even annual revenue level required to achieve NPV = 0, giving them a clear financial floor target for the first five years of operation.

6. R - Reflect (Key Takeaways) 
This final stage synthesizes the financial and strategic findings into core lessons learned and the definitive executive recommendation.
Executive Recommendation
The Starbucks Roastery project is financially attractive, creates significant shareholder value in the base case, and is strategically essential for brand premiumization.
Recommendation: ACCEPT the Investment
Key Takeaways for Management
Value Creation and Return Buffer: The project is sound, with an IRR of 13.25% that provides a strong 4.75% buffer over the 8.5% WACC. The PI of 1.347 confirms that the project is capital-efficient.
Revenue Performance is the Single Greatest Risk: The project is dangerously susceptible to market underperformance. The sensitivity test showed that a 20% drop in revenue makes the project value-destroying (NPV < 0). Marketing and operational excellence must be executed flawlessly, especially in the first five years, to achieve the $11M revenue target.
Strategic Rationale Validates Risk: The investment is justified not only by the positive NPV but also by its role as a strategic brand asset. The Roastery serves as a high-visibility marketing platform that reinforces Starbucks luxury segment, justifying premium pricing and driving traffic to its overall ecosystem. This strategic benefit further strengthens the acceptance decision despite the revenue sensitivity.
Mitigation Strategy: Starbucks must implement a robust monitoring system, focusing on early-year revenue and expense control. If sales trajectories indicate a potential 20% shortfall, management must be ready to quickly cut variable costs or deploy targeted marketing to pull the project back to the break-even point.

Next,
taxes are calculated only on positive
EBIT.
As you can see here,
taxes only apply if EBIT is positive.
And then we have free cash flow. The
final FCF
includes OCF
plus non-operating cash flows.
The results are stored and returned in a
pandas data frame completing the cash
flow schedule requirement.
And you can see we now have the OCF non
operating cash flows and FCF
initial capex and investment working
capital change
and terminal value total free cash
flows. close
and then we can move back to where we
were at.
The calculate metrics function here
processes the FCF series to produce the
core capital budgeting outputs.
NPV and IRR results.
The base case analysis yields an NPV
of
277,485
and an IRR of 8.13%.
Since the NPV is negative and the IRRa
is below the 8.5% WACCC,
the analysis concludes the project is
financially unviable in the base case
directing directly addressing the
decision-making requirement of the
assignment.
And then for for the profitability index
which comes
after the net present value that we've
calculated in the internal rate of
return.
The profitability index is calculated as
the ratio of the present value of future
cash flows which is NPV minus initial
outlay to the initial investment
resulting in 0.98.
And then moving on to simple payback
period. The script accurately calculates
both simple and discounted payback
periods.
Using linear interpolation satisfying a
key assignment requirement,
the simple payback is 8.11 years and the
discounted payback is 9.28 years.
You can see the discount payback period
section here.
And then next we move on to the
sensitivity analysis function.
This function systematically
executes
the required stress tests
revenue down 20% WACC
plus or minus 2%. A sensitivity analysis
is critical to the assignment. The
results show the project is extremely
sensitive to revenue with a 20% drop
plunging the NPV to minus 6.48 million.
So here it's showing scenario A revenue
reduced by 20% and scenario B the debt
VACC
plus 2% and then scenario B is WACC
minus 2%.
Next is the visualization function
which is creating the plot
and the rest of the code goes towards
that. So now we have our output here
which gives us the incremental free cash
flow schedule for years 0 through 10. We
have the hurdle rate WACCC showing at
8.5%.
the core capital budgeting metrics. So
we have the NPV again at negative
277,485,
the IRRa at 8.13%, the PI at 0.98, the
simple payback in years is 8.11, the
discounted payback in years is zero.
Running sensitivity revenue reduced by
20%. WACC plus 2% is 10.5%.
and WHCC minus 2% is 6.5%. We then have
the sensitivity analysis summary with
the base free cash flow schedule shown
as a bar graph as well as the NPV
sensitivity to revenue and WACC changes
bar graph.
These two plots are generated using the
map plot lib function.
the base case FCF schedule over time and
a bar chart showing the NPV sensitivity
across all scenarios visually supporting
the final analytical conclusion. The
project must be rejected due to its
negative base case NPV and lack of
resilience. And that is the end of the
session 10 assignment. Thank you.

And for years 1 through 10, operating cash flow is revenue minus COGS, labor, rent, and marketing and minus straight line depreciation. So I applied the 25% tax rate and then add back depreciation to convert earnings to cash. And year 10 also includes the 3 million terminal value and the recovery of the half million in working capital. So every cash flow is discounted at star uh is discounted at Starbucks walk of 8.5% and from that schedule I computed the MPV IRR the profitability index and both simple and discounted payback. Now going to implement now let's look at the base case results produced by the code. So the MPV is positive at um at MP is positive at $3.02 million and IRRa is 13 IR is 13.25% the probability index is 1.242 simple payback the simple payback is 5.28 28 years and discounted payback discounted payback is 8.21 years. So those figures imply the project clears the company's hurdle rate and creates value in the base case. And now um looking at this first chart, this box plot, this chart shows annual free cash flow from year 0 to year 10. So you can see the large initial outflow at time zero and then steady positive operating cash flows and a final step up in year 10. Then from uh from the terminal value plus working capital recovery and here's the scenario comparison for MPV this third graph here um the base case at 8.5% um WACC is about positive 3.0 Z and if revenue underperforms 20% across the horizon, NPV flips to approximately negative 3 uh 3.0 at 3.16 million which is like 3.0 million and IR falls to just over 3%. So revenue realization is the primary risk driver. And this second graph here, the MPV versus WACC, a chart plots MPV against WCC from 6.5 to 10.5%. Answer: Hi everybody and welcome to my session 10 assignment which covers capital budgeting. Um obviously we're going to be using the driver framework in order to solve this problem and to work through our analysis. Um so we're going to be looking at the cost of capital analysis for a Starbucks's proposed flagship roaster. I'm requiring a $12 million upfront outlay um that's expected to operate for a total period of 10 years using their 8 12% weighted average cost of capital as the hurdle rate. We're going to get into the parameters and everything like that using the driver framework to solve our problem. So first we're going to jump right into the first stage which is define and discover. Really just to look at what do we understand right now? What are our known parameters and what do we need to be figuring out. So our general objective for this problem is to evaluate the $12 million 10-yearong Starbucks flagship roastery project and determine if there is economic value that is created. If there is economic value created, that's a good thing. That's a positive. If there's not, then um this project, this um cash flow thing would not be beneficial. And we're going to look at the weighted average cost of capital at 8 and a half% as well as net present value to kind of understand does this make a little bit of sense. So let's jump a little bit into some known parameters that we have. We calculated and we collected all of these from the stem of the problem given on the textbook. So the first is the initial investment. We know there's a total cash outflow of actually $12.5 million in year 0. It's $12 million of building equipment and training which is depreciated straight line over 10 years. But there's also that $500,000 in working capital which is deployed at launch and then actually only recovered in year 10 nearing the end. The time and rate so this total project length is 10 years and our discount rate for our rated average cost of capital is that 8 12%. A little bit into tax and terminal value. the corporate tax rate is given at 25% and then that terminal value is $3 million and that's the amount of money that's gotten back at the end of year 10. And then in regards to depreciation, this is going to be a straight line depreciation problem over 10 years. Um, which pretty much results in a tax shielding expense of about $1.2 million annually. It's that 12 million divided by that period of 10 years. Now, here are our revenue assumptions down at the bottom. starts off um pretty basic, $8 million of revenue in year 1. And then it skyrockets for the next few years. From years 2 to 5, it's going to be $11 million over those years. And then it slows down just a little bit over the last few years between 6 and 10 going at $9 million a year. Then we have two different types of costs that are always looking that we're always looking at in a problem. The first are variable costs um which change. Variable costs are your cost of goods sold in this problem and that is 40% of your gross revenue. So it's going to change based on your revenue per year.
